note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: _LEt us make uſe of this ſtolne privacy,
And not looſe time in proteſtation, miſtris,
For twere in me a kind of breach of faith,
To ſay againe I love you.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Sweet ſpeake ſoftly
For though the venture of your love to me,
Meetes with a willing, and a full returne:
Should it arrive unto my Fathers knowledge;
Theſe were our laſt diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: How ſhall he know it?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: His watching cares are ſuch, for my advancement,
That every where his eye is fix'd upon me:
This night that does afford us ſome ſmall freedom,
At the requeſt and much entreaty of,
The miſtris of the houſe, was hardly given me:
For I am never ſufferd to ſtir out,
But he hath ſpies upon me, yet I know not
You have ſo won upon me, that could I thinke
You would love faithfully (though to entertaine
Another thought of you, would be my death)
I ſhould adventure on his utmoſt anger.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why, do you thinke I can be falſe?

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: No faith,
You have an honeſt face, but if you ſhould—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let all the ſtored vengeance of heavens juſtice—

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: No more, I do believe you, the dance ended,
Which this free womans gheſts have vow'd to have
Ere they depart, I will make home, and ſtore me
With all the Iewells, Chaines, and gold are truſted
Unto my cuſtody, and at the next corner,
To my Fathers houſe, before one at the fartheſt,
Be ready to receive me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I deſire
No bond beyond your promiſe, let's go in,
To talke thus much before the doore, may breed,
Suſpition. Enter Mercury and Antonio talking.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Here are company too.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Away,
Thoſe powers that proſper true and honeſt loves
Will bleſſe our undertakeings.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: 'Tis my wiſh Sir. Exit Rich and Ʋiol.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, excuſe me, I have drawne you to,
Too much expence already in my travell:
And you have been to forward in your love;
To make my wants your owne, allow me manners
Which you muſt grant I want, ſhould I encreaſe,
The bond in which your courtiſyes have tide me:
Be ſtill conſuming you, give me leave
To take mine owne wayes now; and I ſhall often
With willingneſſe come to viſit you, and then thanke you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By this hand I could be angry, what do you thinke me?
Muſt we that have ſo long time, beene as one
Seene Cityes, Countryes, Kingdomes, and their wonders
Beene bedfellowes, and in our various journey
Mixtall our obſervations, part (as if
We were 2. Carriers at 2. ſeverall wayes,
And as the forehorſe guides, cry God be with you)
Without or complement, or cerimony?
In travelers that know tranſalpine garbes,
Though our deſignes are neere ſo ſerious, friend,
It were a capitall crime; it muſt not be,
Nay what is more, you ſhall not, you ere long
Shall ſee my houſe, and finde what I call mine
Is wholly at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mer,
sp.l: 'Tis this tires me,
Sir I were eaſily woo'd if nothing elſe
But my will lay in the choyce, but 'tis not ſo
My friends and kindred that have part of me,
And ſuch on whom my chiefeſt hopes depend,
Iuſtly expect the tender of my love
After my travell, then mine owne honeſty
Tells me 'tis poore, having indifferent meanes
To keep me in my quallity and rank,
At my returne to tire anothers bounty,
And let mine owne grow luſty, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will not, cannot, to conclude I dare not:
Can any thing confer'd upon my friend
Be burthenſome to me? for this excuſe
Had I no reaſon elſe you ſhould not leave me,
By a travellers faith you ſhould not, I have ſaid,
And then you know my humour, ther's no contending.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is there no way to ſcape this Inundation?
I ſhall be drown'd with folly if I go:
And after 9. dayes men may take me up,
With my gall broken.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you yet reſolv'd?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wood you would ſpare me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By this light I cannot
By all, that may be ſworne by.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Patience helpe me,
And heaven grant his folly be not catching:
If it be, the townes undone, I now would give
A reaſonable ſum of gold to any ſheriff,
That would but lay an execution on me,
And free me from his company; while he was abroad,
His want of witt and language kept him dumbe:
But Balaam's Aſſe will ſpeake now without ſpurring.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speake, have I won you?—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are not to be reſiſted.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Be ready I entreat you the dance done,
Beſides a liberall reward I have,
A bottle of ſherry in my power ſhall beget
New crotchets in your heads.

sp.speaker: Muſit.
sp.l: Tuſh feare not us, wee'le do our parts.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Go in,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know this fellow.
Belong you to the houſe?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I ſerve the Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pretty, and ſhort, pray you ſir then informe her,
Two Gentlemen are covetous to be honour'd,
With her faire preſence.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: She ſhall know ſo much,
This is a merry night with us, and forbid not
Welcom to any that lookes like a man:
I'le guide you the way.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay follow, I have a trick in't. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Ʋberto, Siluio, Richardo, Maria, Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: Come wher's this maſque? faireſt for our cheare,
Our thankes and ſervice, may you long ſurviue,
To joy in many of theſe nights.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: We muſt have muſique too, or ells you give us,
But halfe a welcom.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray you Sir excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.l: By no meanes Lady.

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: Weele crowne your liberall feaſt,
With ſome delightfull ſtraine fitting your love:
And this good company.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Since you enforce it,
I will not plead the excuſe of want of skill
Or be, or nice, or curious, every year,
I celebrate my marriage night; and will
'Till I ſee my abſent husband.

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: 'Tis fit freedome.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.l: Richardo thou art dull—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I ſhall be lighter,
When I have had a heate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now Sir, the newes?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Miſtris there are 2. Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Complementing who ſhould firſt enter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Heaven knowes, but for their ſtrangeneſſe, have you never ſeen a Cat waſh her face?

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Iuſt ſuch a ſtir they keep if you make but haſt,
You may ſee 'em yet before they enter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let 'em be what they will, wee'le give them faire
Entertaine, and gentle welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then let it be your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let's ſtand a ſide and you ſhall ſee us have
Fine ſport anon.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A faire ſociety, do you know theſe Gentle women?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The ſecond is a neighbours daughter, her name is Ʋiola.
There is my kinſmans wife, Portia her name, and a
Friend too.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let her—what's ſhe that leades the dance?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I ſee that.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Udsfoote, good Sir what's ſhe that leades the dance?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: My Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: VVhat els?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: My Miſtris, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Your Miſtris? a pox on you, What a fry of fooles are here? I ſee 'tis treaſon to underſtād in this houſe; if nature were not better to them, then they can be to themſelves, they would ſcant hitt their mouthes; my Miſtris? Is there any one with ſo much witt in 's head, that can tell me at the firſt ſight, what Gentlewoman that is that leades the dance?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis my wife.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How do'ſt thou like her?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: VVell, a pretty Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prethee be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I would I could
Let never any hereafter that's a man,
That has affections in him and free paſſions,
Receive the leaſt tye from ſuch a foole as this is,
That holds ſo ſweet a wife, 'tis lamentable to conſider truly
What right he robbs himſelfe of, and what wrong
He doth the youth of ſuch a Gentlewoman?
That knowes her beauty is no longer hers,
Then men will pleaſe to make it ſo, and uſe it
Neither of which lyes freely in a husband,
O what have I don, what have I don, Coxcomb?
If I had never ſeen, or never taſted
The goodneſſe of this kix, I had beene a made man,
But now to make a Cuckold is a ſinne
Againſt all forgiveneſſe, worſe then a murther;
I have a Woolfe by the eares, and am bitten both wayes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now friend, what are you thinking of?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nothing concerning you, I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pardon me, Ile have no going ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then good ſir give me leave to goe to bed,
I am very weary and ill tempered.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You ſhall preſently, the dance is done.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Miſtris, theſe are the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My husband will come home, deare ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She's faire ſtill, O that I were a knave or durſt be one,
For thy ſake coxcōbe; he that invented honeſty, undid me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I had you had not knowne me, y'are merry tis well thought,
And how iſt with theſe worthy Gent?

sp.speaker: Vb. & Sil.
sp.l: We are glad to ſee you here againe

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh Gent, what ha'you loſt? but get you into travells,
There you may learne, I cannot ſay what hidden vertues.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hidden from you I am ſure,
My blood boyles like a furnace,
Shees a faire one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pray entertaine this Gent. with all the curteſie,
Fitting my moſt eſpeciall friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What this poore houſe may yeild,
To make you welcome deare ſir command
Without more complement.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I thanke you:
Shee's wiſe and ſpeakes well too, oh what a bleſſing
Is gone by me neere to be recovered?
sp.p: Well, twas an old ſhame the Devill laid up for mee, and now has hit me home; if there be any waies to bee diſho|neſt and ſave my ſelfe yet, — No it muſt not bee, why ſhould I bee a foole to —Yet thoſe eyes would tempt another Adam, how they call to me, and tell me — Sfoote they ſhall not tell me any thing, ſir will you walke in.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How iſt Signior?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Crazie a litle.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What ayle you ſir?
Whats in my power pray make uſe of, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Tis that muſt doe me good, ſhe do's not mock me ſure,
An't pleaſe you nothing, my diſeaſe is only wearineſſe.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: Come Gent. weele not keepe you from your bedds too long.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I ha ſome buſineſſe, and tis late, and you far from your lodging.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Well. Exit. Manent, Ant. Mar. and Mer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come my deare Mercury, ile bring you to your chamber, and then I am for you, Maria, thou art a new wife to me now, and thou ſhalt finde it, ere I ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And I, an old aſſe to my ſelfe, mine owne rod whips me, — good ſir no more of this, tis tedious, you
are the beſt guide in your owne houſe — goe ſir —
sp.l: This foole, and his faire wife have made me franticke
From two ſuch phyſickes for the ſoule, deliver me.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: VVell, you muſt have this wench then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I hope ſo, I am much o'th bow hand elſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: VVood I were hangd, tis a good loving little foole that dares venture her ſelfe upon a coaſt ſhe never knew yet, but theſe women, when they are once thirteene, god ſpeede the plough.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Faith they'le venture further, ſo their lading then a Merchant, and through as many ſtormes, but theyle bee franghted, they are made like Carrecks only ſtrength and ſtorage.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Come, come, you talke, you talke.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: VVe doe ſo, but tell me Richardo, woote thou marry her?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Marry her? why what ſhould I do with her?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pox, I thought we ſhould have had all ſhares in her like lawfull prize.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: No by my faith ſir, you ſhall pardon me, I lancht her at my owne charge without partners, and ſo ile keepe her.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: VVhats the houre?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Twelve.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: VVhat ſhall we doe the while? tis yet ſcarce eleven.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Theres no ſtanding here, is not this the place?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And to go back unto her fathers houſe, may breede ſuſpition lets ſlip into a Taverne, for an houre, tis very cold.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Content, there is one hard by, a quart of burnt ſack will recover us, I am as cold as Chri●●mas, this ſtealing fleſh in the froſty weather, may be ſure 'ith eating, but ſure the woodmen have no great catch on't; ſhalls go?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Thou art the ſtrangeſt lover of a taverne, what ſhall we doe there now? looſe the hower and our ſelves too?

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Looſe a pudding; what do'ſt thou talke of the howre; will one quart muzle us? have wee not eares to heare, and tongues to aske the drawers, but wee muſt ſtand here like bawds to watch the minuts?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Prethee content thy ſelfe, we ſhall ſcout here, as though we went a haying, and have ſome mangey pren|tice, that cannot ſleepe for ſcratching, over eare us, come will you goe ſirs? when your love fury is a little frozen, youle come to us.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: VVill you drinke but one quart then?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No more I faith.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: VVhy then, have with you, but letts be very watchfull

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: As watchfull as the belman, come Ile lead, becauſe I hate good manners, they are too tedious. Exeunt.
sp.stage: Enter Viola with a Key and a little Casket.
sp.l: The night is terrible and I enclos'd
With that my vertue and my ſelf hate moſt,
Darkeneſſe; yet muſt I feare that which I wiſh,
Some company, and every ſtep I take
Sounds louder in my fearefull eares to night
Then ever did, the ſhrill and ſacred bell
That rang me to my prayers; the houſe will riſe
When I unlock the doore, were it by day
I am bold enough, but then a thouſand eyes
Warne me from going, might not God have made
A time for envious prying folke to ſleepe
Whilſt lovers met, and yet the ſunne have ſhone?
Yet I was bold enough, to ſteale this key
Out of my fathers Chamber, and dare yet
Venture upon mine enemy, this night,
Arm'd onely with my love, to meet my friend.
Alas how valiant, and how fraid at once
Love makes a Virgin? I will throw this key
Back through a windowe, I had wealth enough
In Iewels with me, if I hold his love
I ſteale e'm for; farewell my place of birth,
I never make account to looke on thee againe;
And if there be as I have heard men ſay,
Theſe houſhold gods, I doe beſeech them looke
To this my charge, bleſſe it from theeves and fire,
And keepe till happily my love I win
Me from thy doore, and hold my Father in. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Richardo, Pedro, Vberto, Silvio, and Drawer with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: No more for God ſake, how is the night boy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Faith ſir tis very late.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Faith ſir you lye, is this your jack i'th clock-houſe? will you ſtrike ſir? gi's ſome more ſack, you varlet.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nay, if you love me, good Vberto goe,
I am monſtrous hot with wine.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Quench it againe with love, Gent. I will-drinke one health more, and then if my leggs ſay mee not ſhamefully nay, I will goe with you, give me a ſingular quart.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Of what wine ſir?

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: Of Sack, you that ſpeake confuſion at the bar, of ſack I ſay, and every one his quart, what a devill letts be merry.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: You ſhall ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: We will ſir, and a dryed tongue.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And an Olive, boy, and a whole bunch of fidlers, my head ſwimmes plaguely, vds pretious I ſhall be claud.

div.stage: Enter Drawer with foure quarts of wine.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Pray goe, I can drinke no more, thinke on your promiſe, tis midnight Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: O that it were dum midnight now, not a word more, every man on's knees, and betake himſelfe to his ſaint, heer's to your wench, ſeigneour, all this, & then away.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I cannot drinke it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Tis a toy, a toye, away wo't.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: Now dare I ſpeake any thing, to any body living, come whers the fault? off with it.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I have broke my wind, call you this ſack?— I wonder who made it? he was a ſure workeman, for tis plaguy ſtrong worke, is it gone round?

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.p: Tis at the laſt out of my way, good boy, is the moon up yet?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: Where is ſhe boy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: There ſir.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: We ſhall have raine and thunder, boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: When ſir?

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but ſure we ſhall, boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: The Gent. is wine wiſe.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Here ſir.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: Can you procure?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: What ſir?

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: A whore or two or three as need ſhall ſerve, boy?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I, a good whore were worth money, boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I proteſt ſir we are all together unprovided.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: The mor's the pitty, boy, can you not vize us where my child?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Neither, in troth ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why where were you brought up boy? no jugling of a whore? no ayme my boy?

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: It cannot ſink in my head now, that thou ſhouldſt marry, why ſhouldſt thou marry, tell me?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I marry? Ile be hang'd firſt: ſome more wine boy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Is ſhe not a whore tranſlated? & ſhe be, lets repaire to her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I cannot tell, ſhe may be an offender; but ſignior Silvio I ſhall ſcratch your head, indeed I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Judge me I do moſt jeſt with thee, what an ſhe were inverted with her heeles upward, like a traitors Coate? what care I.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: I, hang her, ſhall we fall out for her?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I am a little angry, but theſe wenches, did you not talke of wenches?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Boy lend me your candle.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: VVhy Sir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: To ſet fire to your rotten feeling, you'le keep no
Whores, Rogue, no good members;

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: VVhores Sir?

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.p: I, whores, Sir, do you think we come to lye with your hogsheads?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I muſt beate the watch, I have long'd for't any time this three weekes.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.p: VVee'le beate the towne too, and thou wilt, we are proofe boy; ſhall wee kill any body?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: No but wee'le hurt 'em dangerouſly.

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.p: Silu. Now muſt I kill one, I cannot avoide it, boy eaſily afore there with your candle; wher's your Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: A bed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: VVith whom?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: VVith my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.p: You lye Boy, ſhee's better brought up then to lye with her husband, has he not caſt his head yet? next yeare he will be a velvet-headed Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: You are a merry Gentleman, there Sir, take hold Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: This is the place I have out told the Clock,
For haſt, he is not here. Richardo? no;
Now every power that loves and is belov'd:
Keep me from ſhame to night, for all you know
Each thought of mine is innocent, and pure,
As fleſh and blood can hold: I cannot back;
I threw the key within, and ere I raiſe
My Father up, to ſee his daughters ſhame,
I'le ſet me downe, and tell the Northern winde,
That it is gentler then the curling Weſt;
If it will blow me dead, but he will come;
I faith 'tis cold; if hee deceive mee thus,
A woman will not eaſily truſt a man. Hark what's that?

sp.speaker: Sil within.
sp.p: Th'art over long at thy pott, tom, tom, thou art over long at the pott tom.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Bleſſe me! whoſe that?

sp.speaker: Pedro within.
sp.l: Whoo!

sp.speaker: Ʋber. within.
sp.l: There Boyes.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Darkeneſſe be thou my cover, I muſt fly,
To thee I haſt for help —

div.stage: Enter Richardo, Pedro, Ʋberto, Drawer with a torch.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: They have a light,
Winde if thou lov'ſt a virgine blow it out,
And I will never ſhut a window more,
To keep thee from me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Boy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why Boy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: What ſay you Sir?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why boy? art thou drunk boy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: What would you Sir?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why very good, where are wee?

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: I, that's the point.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Why Sir, you will be at your lodging preſently.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I'le go to no lodging Boy.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: VVhether will you go then Sir?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I'le go no farther.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: For Gods ſake Sir, do not ſtay here all night.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: No more I will not boy, lay me downe, and rowle me to a whore.

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: And mee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There ſpoke an —

sp.speaker: Silvio.
sp.l: Then ſet your foote to my foote, & up tailes all.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: That is Richardo, what a noyſe they make?
'Tis ill don on 'em: heere Sirs, Richardo?

sp.speaker: Rich..
sp.l: What's that Boy?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: 'Tis a wench Sir, pray Gent. come away.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: O my deare love! how doeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: My ſweet hart? even as thou ſeeſt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Wher's thy wench?

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: VVher's this bed worme?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Speake ſoftly for the love of heaven.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Miſtris get you gone, and doe not entice the gent. now you ſee thei're drunke, or Ile call the watch, and lay you faſt enough.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Alas what are you? or what doe you meane?
Sweet love wher's the place?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Marry ſweet love, ee'n here, lye downe Ile feeſe you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Good god! what meane you?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ile have the wench.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: If you can get her.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: No Ile lye with the wench to night, and ſhe ſhall be yours to morrow.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Let goe the wench.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Let you goe the wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O Gent. as you had mothers!

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: They had no mothers, they are the ſons of bitches

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Let that be maintain'd.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Marry then.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh bleſſe me heaven!

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: How many is there ons?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: About five.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: Why then lets fight three to three. Draw and fall downe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The watch? the watch? the watch? where are you? Exit.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Where are theſe cowards?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ther's the whore.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I never ſaw a drunken man before,
But theſe I thinke are ſo.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I miſt you narrowly there.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My ſtate is ſuch, I know not how to thinke,
A prayer fit for me, only I could move,
That never maiden more might be in love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Where are they, boy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Make no ſuch haſt ſir, they are no runners.

sp.speaker: Vb.
sp.l: I am hurt, but that's all one, I ſhall light upon ſome of ye,
Pedro thou art a tall Gent. let me kiſſe thee.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: My friend.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: Your friend? you ly.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Stand further off, the watch, you are full of fleas.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Gent either be quiet, or we muſt make you quiet.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay good Mr. Conſtable, be not ſo Rigorous.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.l: Mr. Conſtable lend me thy hand of juſtice.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: That I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Vber.
sp.p: Fy M^r. Conſtable what golls you have? is juſtice ſo blind ſhe cannot ſee to waſh your hands? I cry you mercy Sir; Your gloves are one.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Now you are up Sir, will you go to bed?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I'le truckle heere Boy, give me another pillow.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: VVill you ſtand up and let me lay it on then?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: There hold him two of yee, now they are up be going M^r. Conſtable

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: And this way, and that way, tom.

sp.speaker: Ʋber.
sp.l: And heere away and there away tom.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.l: This is the right way the others the wrong.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Th' others the wrong.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thou art over long at the pott tom, tom.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Lead valiantly ſweet Conſtable, whoop! ha Boyes!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: This wine hunts in their heads.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Give me the bill, for I'le bee the Sergeant.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Looke to him Sirs.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Keep your Ranks you Raſcalls, keep your Ranks.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: I Cannot ſleep for thinking of this Aſſes wife, I'le be gon preſently, ther's no ſtaying heere, with this Divell about me? hoe, this is the houſe of ſleep, hoe? againe ther's foote the darkneſſe, and this love to|gether, will make mee lunaticke; ho?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Pray take the paines to riſe and light a candle.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Preſently,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Was ever man but I in ſuch a ſtockes? well this ſhal be a warning to me, and a faire one too, how I betray my ſelfe to ſuch a dunce, by way of benefit.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Did you call?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, pray doe me the kindneſſe ſir, to let me out and not to enquire why, for I muſt needs be gone.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Not to night, I hope ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good ſir to night, I would not have troubled you elſe, pray let it be ſo.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Alas ſir, my Maſter will be offended.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That I have buſineſſe? no I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Good ſir take your reſt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Pray my good friend let me appoint my owne reſt.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then ſhew me the way out, I'le conſider you.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Good Lord, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If I had not an excellent tempered patience, now ſhould I breake this fellowes head, and make him un|derſtand 'twere neceſſary; the onely plague of this houſe is the unhandſome love of ſervants, that neere doe their duty in the right place, but when they muſter before din|ner, and ſweep the table with a wodden dagger, and then they are troubleſom too, to all mens ſhoulders, the Wood|cocks fleſht agen, now I ſhall have a new ſtir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: VVhy how now friend? what do you up ſo late? are you well? do you want any thing? pray ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Onely the cauſe I riſe for.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What knaues are theſe? what do you want? why ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nothing i'the world, but the keyes to let me out of dores; I muſt be gon, bee not againſt it, for you cannot ſtay me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Begon at this time? that were a merry jeſt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If there be any mirth in't, make you uſe on't, but I muſt go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why for loves ſake?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Twill benefit your underſtanding nothing to know the cauſe, pray go to bed, I'le trouble your man only.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay Sir you have rais'd more, that has reaſon to curſe you, and you knew all, my wifes up, and comming downe too.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Alas it will be a trouble, pray go up to her and let me diſturbe no more, 'tis unmannerly.

div.stage: Enter Wife as out of her bed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Shee's here already; ſweet hart: how ſay you by this Gentleman? he would away at midnight.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That I am ſure hee will not.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Indeed I muſt.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Good Sir let not your homely entertainement preſſe you to leave your bed at midnight; if you want, what my houſe or your towne may afford you, make it your own fault if you call not for it pray go to bed again; let me compell you, I am ſure you have no power to de|nye a woman; the ayre is piercing, & to a body beaten with long travell, 'twill prove an ill Phyſitian.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If ſhe ſpeake longer I ſhall be a knaue, as ranke as ever ſweat for't; Sir if you will ſend your wife up preſent|ly, I will either ſtay with you, d'ye marke, me or deliver you, ſo juſt a cauſe, that you your ſelfe, ſhall thruſt me out of doores, both ſuddainly and willingly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I would faine heare that faith, pray thee go up ſweet hart, I have halfe perſwaded him, beſides, he hath ſome private buſineſſe with mee.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good night Sir, and what content you would have, I wiſh with you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Could any man that had a back aske more? o me! o me!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now deale directly with me: why ſhould you go?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If you be wiſe do not enquire the cauſe, 'twill trou|ble you:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVhy? prithee why?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith I would not have you know it, let me go, 'twill be far better for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who's that, that knocks there? i'ſt not at the ſtreet doore?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who's there, cannot you ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Within Vio.
sp.l: A poore diſtreſſed maid, for gods ſake let me in.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Let her in and me out together, 'tis but one labour, tis pity ſhee ſhould ſtand ith' ſtreet, it ſeemes ſhe knowes you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There ſhee ſhall ſtand for me, you are ignorant; this is a common cuſtome of the Rogues that lie about the looſe parts of the City.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To knock at doores in dead time of night, and uſe ſome fained voyce to raiſe compaſſion, and when the doores are open, in they ruſh, and cut the throats of all and take the booty, we cannot be too carefull.

sp.speaker: Within Ʋi.
sp.l: As ever you had pity let me in, I am undone elſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My name is Viola, a Gentlewoman, that ill chance hath diſtreſſed, you know my father,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Alas of god we'll let her in, 'tis one of the Gen|tlewomen were here ith' evening, I know her by her name, (poore ſoule) ſhee's cold I warrant her, let her have my warme Bed, and Ile take her fortune; come, pray come.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is not Viola that's certaine, ſhe went home to her fathers, I am ſure,

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Will not you be ſo good to let me in?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ile be ſo good to have you whipt away if you ſtay a litle longer: Shee's gone I warrant her, now let mee know your cauſe for I will heare it, and not repent the knowing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Since you are ſo importunate, I'le tell you, I love your wife extreamly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Uery well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And ſo well that I dare not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVhy?

sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.p: For wronging you, I know I am fleſh and blood, and you have done me friendſhips infinite and often, that muſt require me honeſt and a true man, and I will be ſo or I'le breake my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVhy, you may ſtay for all this, me thinks.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, though I wood be good, I am no ſaint, nor is it ſafe to try mee, I deale plainely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come I dare try you, do the beſt you can.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You ſhall not when I am right agen, I'le come and ſee you, till when, I'le uſe all Countryes and all meanes, but I will looſe this folly, 'tis a Divell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is there no way to ſtay you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, unles you will have me ſuch a villaine to you as all men ſhall ſpit at mee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do's ſhe know you love her?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No I hope not, that were recompence fit for a Rogue to render her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If ever any had a faithfull friend I am that man, and I may glory in't, this is he, that ipſe, he that paſſes all Chriſtendome for goodneſſe, hee ſhall not over go me in his friendſhip twere recreant and baſe, and I'le be hang'd firſt, I am reſolv'd, go thy wayes, a wife ſhall never part us, I have conſider'd and I finde her nothing to ſuch a friend as thou art; I'le ſpeake a bold word, take your time and woe her, you have overcome me cleerely, and do what's fitting with her, you conceive mee, I am glad at hart you love her: by this light, ne're ſtare upon me for I will not flye from it, if you had ſpoken ſooner, ſure you had bin ſerv'd; Sir, you are not every man, now to your taske, I give you free leave, and the ſinne is mine if there be any in it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Hee will be hang'd before he makes this good, hee cannot be ſo innocent a Coxcombe, he can tell ten ſure, if I had never knowne you as I have done, I might be one, as others perhaps ſooner, but now 'tis impoſſible ther's too much good betweene us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well thou art een the beſt man—I can ſay no more, I am, ſo over joy'd, you muſt ſtay this night, and in the morning go as earely as you pleaſe, I have a toy for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I thought this pill would make you ſicke.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But where you meane to be I muſt have notice,
And it muſt be hard by too, do you marke me?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There is a thing in hand.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why? what thing?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A ſound one, if it take right, and you be not peeviſh We two will be—you would little thinke it; as fa|mous for our friendſhip—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If God pleaſe, as ever Damon was and Pytheas or Py|lades, and Oreſtes, or any two that ever were: do you con|ceive me yet?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No by my troth Sir; he will not help me up ſure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You ſhall anon, and for our names, I thinke they ſhal live after us, and be remember'd while there is a ſtory; or I looſe my aime.

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: What a vengeance ailes hee? how do you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes faith, wee two wilbe ſuch friends as the world ſhall ring off.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And why is all this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You ſhall enjoy my wife.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The wonder muſt begin, ſo I have caſt it, 'twill be ſcurvy elſe, you ſhall not ſtirr a foote i'nt, pray be quiet 'till I have made it perfect.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What ſhall a man do with this wretched fellow? there is no mercy to be uſed towards him, he is not capa|ble of any pitty, he will in ſpight of courſe be a Cuckold, And who can help it? muſt it begin ſo needs Sir?— thinke agen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes marry muſt it, and I my ſelfe will woe this wo|man for you, do you perceive it now? ha?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes now I have a little ſight i'th matter; o that thy head ſhould be ſo monſtrous, that al thy Servants hatts may hang upon't! but do you meane to do this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes certaine, I will woe her, and for you, ſtrive not againſt it, 'tis the overthrow of the beſt plott that ever was then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay I'le aſſure you Sir, I'le do no harme, you have too much about you of your owne.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Have you thought of a place yet?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A place?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I a place where you will bide, pre'thee no more of this modeſty, 'tis fooliſh, and we were not determinde to be abſolute friends indeed, 'twere tolerable.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I have thought, and you ſhall heare from me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why? this will gaine me everlaſting glory; I have the better of him, that's my comfort, good night. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good night, well go thy wayes, thou art the ty|dieſt wittall this day I thinke above ground, and yet thy end for all this muſt bee mottly. Exit.

div.stage: Enter a Tincker, with a cord, and Dorathy.

sp.speaker: Tinck.
sp.p: 'Tis bitter cold; a plague upon theſe Rogues, how wary they are growne? not a doore open now, but double bard, not a window, but up with a caſe of wood like a ſpice box, and their locks unpickable, the very ſmithes that were halfe venturers, drink penitent ſingle Ale, this is the Iron age, the Ballad ſings of; well I ſhall meet with ſome of our looſe Linnen yet, good fel|lowes muſt not ſtarve; heer's he ſhall ſhew you God a mighties dog bolts, if this hold.

sp.speaker: Dorathy.
sp.p: Faith thou art but too mercifull, that's thy fault thou art as ſweete a thiefe, that ſin excepted ever ſufferd, that's a proud word and I'le maintaine it.

sp.speaker: Tinck.
sp.p: Come prethee let's ſhogg off, & brouze an how|er or two, ther's ale will make a Cat ſpeake, at the har|row, we ſhall get nothing now, without we batter, 'tis growne too neere morning, the Rogues ſleep ſober, and are watchfull.

sp.speaker: Dorit.
sp.p: Wee want a Boy extreamely for this function kept under for a yeare, vvith milke and knott-graſſe; in my time I have ſeene a boy do vvonders Robbin the red Tinck|er had a boy Reſt his ſoule he ſufferd this time 4. yeares for two ſpoones, & a Pevvter Candleſtick, that ſvveet man had a Boy as I am Curſtend Whore, vvould have run through a Cat hole, he vvold have boulted ſuch a peece of linen in an evening—

sp.speaker: Tinck.
sp.p: Well, vve vvill have a Boy, prethee lets go, I am vengeance cold I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Dorithy.
sp.p: I'le be hang'd before I ſtirr vvithout ſome pur|chaſe by theſe ten bones, I'le turne ſhe ape and untile a houſe, but I'le have it, it may be I have an humour to bee hang'd, I cannot tell

sp.speaker: Tinck.
sp.p: Peace, you flead vvhore, thou haſt a mouth like a Bloodhounde, heere comes a night ſhade.

sp.speaker: Dorit.
sp.p: A Gentlevvoman vvhore, by this darkeneſſe I'le caſe her to the skin.

sp.speaker: Tinck.
sp.l: Peace I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: What feare have I endured this diſmall night?
And vvhat diſgrace if I vvere ſeene and knovvne?
In vvhich this darkeneſſe, onely is my friend,
That onely has undone me; a thouſand curſes
Light on my eaſy, fooliſh childiſh, love,
That durſt ſo lightly lay a confidence
Upon a man, ſo many being falſe;
my wearineſſe, and weeping makes me ſleepie, I muſt lye downe.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: VVhats this? a prayer, or a homilie, or a Ballad of good councell? ſhe has a gowne, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Knock out her braines and then ſhee'le neere byte

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.l: Yes I will knock her, but not yet, you? woman?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: For gods ſake what are you?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: One of the groomes of your wardrobe, come un|caſe, uncaſe; byr lady a good Kerſey.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Pray doe not hurt me ſir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Lets have no pitty, for if you doe, heres that ſhall cutt your whiſtle.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Alas what would you have? I am as miſerable as you can mak me any way.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That ſhall be tryde.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Here, take my gowne if that will doe you pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Yes marry will it, looke in the pockets Doll, there may be birds.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: They are flown a pox goe vvith them, I'le have this Hatt, and this Ruffe too, I like it, novv vvill I flouriſh like a Lady, brave I faith boy.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Y'are ſo gentle people to my ſeeming,
That by my truth I could live vvith you.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Could you ſo? a pretty young round vvench, vvell bloudded, I am for her, theeves.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: But by this I am not, coole your Godpiece, Rogue, or Ile clap a ſpell upon't, ſhall take your edge off with a very vengeance.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Peace horſe-fleſh, peace, Ile caſt off my Amazon, ſhe has walked too long, and is indeede notorious, ſheele fight and ſcould, and drinke like one of the worthies.

sp.speaker: Dort.
sp.p: Vds pretious you young contagious whore muſt you be ticing? and is your fleſh ſo wrank ſir, that two may live upon't? I am glad to heare your cortall growne ſo luſty; he was dry foundered tother day, wee hee my pampered lade of Aſia.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Good woman doe not hurt me, I am ſorry that I have given any cauſe of anger.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Either binde her quickly and come away, or by this ſteele Ile tell though I truſſe for company; now could I eate her broyld, or any way, without vinegar, I muſt have her noſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: By any thing you love beſt, good ſir, good woman.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.l: Why her noſe Dorithy?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If I have it not and preſently and warme, I looſe that I goe withall.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Wood the Devill had that thou goeſt withall, and thee together, for ſure he got thy whelps if thou haſt any, ſhees thy deere dad, whore! put up your cutpurſe; an I take my ſwich up, twill be a black time with you elſe ſheth your bung whore.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Will you binde her? we ſhall ſtand here prating and be hang both.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.l: Come I muſt bind you, not a word, no crying.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Doe what you will, indeed I will not cry.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Hurt her not, if thou doſt by Ale and Beare Ile clout thy old bald braine pan, with a peece of braſſe, you bitch incarnate.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: O God to what am I reſerved, that knew not
Through all my childiſh howers and actions
More ſinne then poore imagination,
And too much loving of a faithleſſe man?
For which I am paid, and ſo, that not the day
That now is riſing to protect the harmeleſſe,
And give the innocent a ſanctuary
From theeves and ſpoylers, can deliver me
From ſhame, at leaſt ſuſpition—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sirrah leade downe the horſes eaſily, I'le walke a foot till I be downe the hill, tis very early, I ſhall reach home betimes. How now, whoſe there?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Night that was ever friend to lovers, yet
Has rais'd ſome weary ſoule, that hates his bed
To come and ſee me bluſh, and then laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: H'ad a rude heart that did this.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Gentle ſir,
If you have that which honeſt men call pitty,
And be as far from evill as you ſhew;
Helpe a poore maide, that this night by bad fortune
Has beene thus us'd by Robbers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A pox upon his heart that would not helpe thee, this theefe was halfe a Lawyer, by his bands, how long have you bin tyed here?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Alas this hower, and with cold and feare am al|moſt periſht.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where were the watch the while? good ſober Gent. they were like carefull members of the City, drawing in diligent ale and ſinging catches, while Mr. Conſtable con|trived the toſts: theſe fellowes would bee more ſeverely puniſht then wandring Gipſies, that every ſtat●te whipps, for if they had every one two eyes a peece more, three pots would put them out.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I cannot tell I found no Chriſtian to give me ſuc|cour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: When they take a theefe, I'le take Oſtend agen; the whorſons drinke opium in their Ale, & then they ſleep like topps; as for their bills, they onely ſerve to reach downe Bacon to make Raſhers on; now let mee know whom I have done this courteſie too, that I may thanke my early riſing for it?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Sir, All I am, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Val
sp.p: You have a name I'm ſure, and a kindred, a father, friend or ſomething that muſt owne you; ſhee's a hand|ſome young wench; what Rogues were theſe to Rob her?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Sir you ſee all I dare reveale,
And as you are a Gent preſſe me no further;
For there begins a griefe whoſe bitterneſſe
Will breake a ſtronger heart then I have in me,
And twill but make you heavie with the hearing,
For your owne goodneſſe ſake deſire it not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you would not have me enquire that, how do you live then?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: How I have lived, is ſtill one queſtion,
Which muſt not be reſolu'd—
How I deſire to live, is in your liking,
So worthy an opinion I have of you,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is in my liking? how I pray thee? tell me, ifaith I'le do you any good lys in my power; ſhe has an eye would raiſe a bedrid man; come leave your feare and tell mee, thats a good wench.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Sir I would ſerve—

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Who wouldſt thou ſerve? doe not weepe and tell me.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Faith ſir even ſome good woman, and ſuch a wife if you be married, I doe imagine yours.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Alas! thou art young and tender, let me ſee thy hand, this was neere made to waſh or wind up water, beate cloaths, or rub a floore, by this light, for one uſe that ſhall be nameleſſe, tis the beſt wanton hand that ere I looke on.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Dare you accept me ſir, my heart is honeſt,
Among your vertuous charitable deeds,
This will not be the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Thou canſt in a Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ʋio
sp.l: In a Chamber ſir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: I meane waite there upon a Gentlewoman,
How quick ſhe is, I like that mainely too;
Ile have her, though I keepe her with maine ſtrength
like a beſieged towne, for I know I ſhall have the enemy afore me within a weeke.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Sir I can ſow too, and make pretty laces,
Dreſſe a head handſome, teach young gentlewomen,
For in all theſe I have a little knowledge.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Tis well, no doubt I ſhall encreaſe that know|ledge; I like her better ſtill, how ſhe provokes me; pritty youngmaid you ſhall ſerve a good Gentlewoman, though I ſay't that will not be unwilling you ſhould pleaſe mee, nor I forgetfull if you doe.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: I am the happier.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: My man ſhall make ſome ſhift to carry you behind him, can you ride well?

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: But I'le hold faſt for catching of a fall.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: That's the next way to pull another on you, I'le worke her as I go I know ſhee's wax, now, now, at this time could I begett a worthy on this wench.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Sir for this Gentleneſſe, may heaven requite you tenfold.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: 'Tis a good vvench hovv ever others uſe thee, be ſure I'le bee a loving maſter to thee, come. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Antonio like an Iriſh Footman, with a letter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I hope I am vvilde enough for being knovvne I have vvrit a letter here, and in it have abus'd my ſelfe moſt bitterly, yet all my feare is not enough, for that muſt do it, that muſt lay it on, I'le vvin her out i'th flint, 'tvvill be more famous, novv for my language.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Now Sir vvho vvould you ſpeake vvith?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where be thy Maſtres man? I vvould ſpeake vvith her.
I have a letter.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Cannot I deliver it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No by my trot and fait can'ſt thou not man.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Well Sir I'le call her to you, pray ſhake your eares vvithout a little. Exit. Servingman.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Cran a Cree do it quickly; this rebbell tonge ſticks in my teeth vvorſe then a toughe hen, ſure it vvas nere knovvne at Babell, for they ſoul'd no apples, and this vvas made for certaine at the firſt planting of Orchards 'tis ſo crabbed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Whats he wood ſpeake with me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: A kill kenny ring, there he ſtands Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What would you have with me, friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He has a letter for other women, wilt thou read it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: De Croſſe creeſt from my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who is your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I pray do you looke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Doe you know this fellow?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No Maddam not I; more then an Iriſh footman ſtand further friend, I doe not like your roperunners, what ſtallion Rogues are theſe, to weare ſuch dovvſetts, the very Cotton may commit adultery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I cannot find whoſe hand this ſhould be, Ile reade, to the beauteous vvife of Don Antonio, ſure this is ſome blind ſcrib —vvell novv vvhat follovves?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray God it take, I have given her, that will ſtirr her conſcience, how it workes with her; hope if it be thy will let the fleſh have it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is the moſt abhor'd, intollerable knavery, that ever ſlave entertain'd, ſure there is more then thine owne head in this villany, it goes like practic'd miſcheife, diſabled in his body? o good God, as I live he lyes feare|fully, and baſely, ha? I ſhould know that Iewell, 'tis my husband, come hither ſhat, are you an Iriſh man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweete woman a Cree I am an Iriſh man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now I know it perfectly; is this your trick Sir? I'le trick you for it; how long have you ſerv'd this Gentle|man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pleaſe thee a little day, o my Mac dermond put me to my maſtree, 'tis don I know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By my faith he ſpeakes as well as if he had been louſy for the language a yeare or two; well Sir, you had bin better have kept your owne ſhape as I will uſe you, what have I don that ſhould deſerve this tryall, I never made him cuckold to my knowledge, Sirrah com hither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now will ſhe ſend ſome Iewell, or ſome letter
I know her minde as well; I ſhall be famous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take this Iriſh bawde heere.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And kicke him till his breeches and breech bee of one colour a bright blew both.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I may be well ſwing'd thus, for I dare not reveale my ſelfe, I hope ſhee does not meane it, o hone o hone, o St. Patricke, o a Cree, o ſweet woman.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: No turne him and kick him o tother ſide, that's well

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O good waiting man, I beſeech thee good waiting man, a pox fyre your leggs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You Rogue you enimy to all, but little breeches how darſt thou come to me with ſuch a letter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prethee pitty the poore Iriſhman, all this makes for me, if I win her yet, I am ſtill more glorious.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now could I weep at what I have don, but I'le harden my hart agen, go ſhut him up, 'till my husband comes home, yet thus much ere ye go, ſirrah thatch'd head, would'ſt not thou be whipt & think it juſtice? well Aqua|vitae Barrell, I will bounce you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I pray do, I beſeech you be not angry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O you hobby headed Raskall, I'le have you flead, and troſſers made of thy skin to tumble in, go a way with him, let him ſee no ſun, 'till my husband come home, ſir I ſhall meet with you for your knavery, I feare it not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wilt thou not let mee go? I do not like this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p: Come I'le lead you in by your Iacke a lent haire, go quietly or I'le make your crupper cracke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And do you heare me ſirrah? and when you have done, make my Coach ready.

sp.speaker: Serving.
sp.p: Yes forſooth. Exit. Servingman with Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Locke him up ſafe enough I'le to this Gentleman,
I know the reaſon of all this buſineſſe, for I do ſuſpect it,
If he have this plott, I'le ring him ſuch a peale, ſhall make his eares deafe for a moneth at leaſt. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Am I not mad? can this weake temper'd head,
That will be mad with drink, endure the wrong
That I have done a virgin and my love?
Be mad, for ſo thou ought'ſt, or I vvill beate
The vvalls and trees, dovvne vvith thee, and vvill let
Either thy memory out or madneſſe in,
But ſure I never lov'd faire Ʋiola:
I never lov'd my Father nor my Mother,
Or any thing but drinke; had I had love;
Nay, had I knovvne ſo much charity,
As would have ſav'd an Infant from the fire,
I had bin naked, raving in the ſtreet:
With halfe a face, gaſhing my ſelfe with knives,
Two howers ere this time.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Good morrow Sir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Good morrow Gentlemen, ſhal we go drink agen?
I have my witts.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: So have I but they are unſetled ones, would I had ſome porrige.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The taverne boy was here this morning with mee
And told me that there was a Gentlewoman,
Which he tooke for a whore that hung on me:
For whom we quarrel'd, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I faith nor I.

sp.speaker: Ʋbe.
sp.l: I have a glimmering of ſome ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Was it you Silvio,
That made me drinke ſo much? 'twas you or Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know not who.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: We were all apt enough.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But I wil lay the fault on none but me,
That I would be ſo entreated, come Silvio,
Shall we goe drinke agen, come Gentlemen,
Why do you ſtay, let's never leave off now,
Whilſt we have Wine and throates, I'le practiſe it,
Till I have made it my beſt quality;
For what is beſt for me to do but that?
For Gods ſake come and drinke; when I am nam'd
Men ſhall make anſwer, which Richado meane you?
The excellent drinker? I will have it ſo,
Will you goe drinke?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.l: We drunke too much too lately.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why there is then the leſſe behind to drinke,
Let's end it all, diſpatch that, wee'l ſend abroad,
And purchaſe all the Wine the world can yield,
And then drinke it off, then take the fruits o'the earth,
Diſtill the Juice from them, and drinke that off;
Wee'l catch the raine before it fall to ground,
And drinke off that that never more may grow;
Wee'l ſet our mouths to Springs, and drinke them off,
And all this while wee'l never thinke of thoſe
That love us beſt, more then we did laſt night.
We will not give unto the poore a drop
Of all this drinke, but when we ſee them weepe,
Wee'l run to them, and drinke their teares off too,
Wee'l never leave whilſt there is heate or moyſture,
In this large globe, but ſuck it cold and dry,
Till we have made it Elementall earth,
Meerly by drinking.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is't flattery to tell you, you are mad?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: If it be falſe,
There's no ſuch way to bind me to a man;
He that will have me, lay my goods and lands,
My life down for him, need no more, but ſay
Richardo thou art mad, and then all theſe
Are at his ſervice, then he pleaſes me,
And makes me thinke that I had vertue in me,
That I had love, and tenderneſſe of heart,
That though I have committed ſuch a fault,
As never creature did, yet runinng mad,
As honeſt men ſhould doe for ſuch a crime,
I have expreſt ſome worth, though it be late:
But I alas have none of theſe in me,
But keep my wits ſtill like a frozen man,
That had no fire within him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nay good Richardo leave this wild talk, and ſend a letter to her, I'le deliver it.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: 'Tis to no purpoſe; perhaps ſhe's loſt laſt night,
Or ſhe got home agen, ſhe's now ſo ſtrictly
Look'd to, the wind can ſcarce come to her, or admit
She were her ſelfe; if ſhe would hear from me,
From me unworthy, that have us'd her thus,
She were ſo fooliſh, that ſhe were no more
To be beloved. Enter Servant with a Night-gown.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, we have foūd this night-gown ſhe took with her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Where? where? ſpeake quickly.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Searching in the Suburbs, we found a Tinker and his whore, that had in it a ſap-houſe, whom we apprehen|ded, and they confeſt they ſtole it from her.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: And murthered her?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What aile you Man?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why all this doth not make me mad.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: It does, you would not offer this elſe, good Pedro looke to his ſword.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They do deny the killing of her, but ſwore they left her tyed to a tree, in the fields, next thoſe Suburbs that are without our Ladies gate, neer day, & by the rode, ſo that ſome paſſinger muſt needs unty her quickly.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: The will of heaven be done? Sir I wil only entreat you this, that as you were the greateſt occaſion of her loſſe, that you will be pleaſed to urge your friends, and be your ſelfe earneſt in the ſearch of her; if ſhe be found, ſhe is yours, if ſhe pleaſe, I my ſelfe only, ſee theſe people bet|ter examin'd, and after follow ſome way in ſearch, God keepe you Gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Alas good man!

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: VVhat think you now of me, I think this lump
Is nothing but a piece of fleagme congeal'd
VVithout a ſoule, for where theres ſo much ſpirit
As would but warm a flea, thoſe faults of mine
VVould make it glow and flame in this dull heart,
And run like molten gold through every ſin,
Till it could burſt theſe walls and fly away.
Shall I intreat you all to take your horſes,
And ſearch this innocent?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: VVith all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Do not devide your ſelves till you come there,
VVhere they ſay ſhe was ty'd, I'le follow too,
But never to return till ſhe be found.
Give me my ſword good Pedro, I will do
No harme believe me with it, I am now
Farre better temper'd, If I were not ſo,
I have enow beſides, God keep you all,
And ſend us good ſucceſſe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: WHo is it? can you tell?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: By my troth Sir I know not, but 'tis a Gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A Gentleman I'le lay my life you puppy, h'as ſent his wife to me: if he have, fling up the bed.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here ſhe is Sir.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: I am glad I found you Sir, there take your letter and keepe it till you have another friend to wrong, 'tis too malicious falſe to make me ſin, you have provoked mee to be that I love not, a talker, and you ſhall heare me.
sp.l: VVhy ſhould you dare to imagine me
So light a huſwife, that from four hours knowledge
You might preſume to offer to my credite
This rude and ruffian tryall, I am ſure
I never courted you, nor gave you tokens,
That might concerne aſſurance, you are a foole.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I cannot blame you now, I ſee this letter
Though you be angry, yet with me you muſt not,
Unleſſe you'l make me guilty of a wrong,
My worſt affections hate—

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.l: Did not you ſend it?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
No upon my faith, which is more, I under|ſtand
it not; the hand is as far from my knowledg, as the malice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This is ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: It is ſo, and had been ſtranger, and indeed more hatefull,
Had ●, that have receiv'd ſuch courteſies, & owe ſo many
Thanks, done this baſe office.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Your name is at it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, but not my nature, and I ſhall hate my name worſe then the manner, for this baſe broking; you are wiſe and vertuous, remove this fault from me; for on the love I beare to truth and goodneſſe, this letter dare not name me for the author.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now I perceive my husbands knavery, if my man can but finde where he has been, I will goe with this Gen|tleman whatſoever comes on't: and as I meane to carry it both he and all the world ſhall thinke it fit, and thank me for it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I muſt confeſſe I loved you, at firſt, however this made me leave your houſe unmannerly, that might pro|voke me to do ſomething ill, both to your honour & my faith, and not to write this letter, which I hold ſo truly wicked, that I will not thinke on't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I do beleeve you, and ſince I ſee you are free, my words were not meant to you, but this is not the halfe of my affliction.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis pitty you ſhould know more vexation; may I enquire?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Faith Sir I feare I have loſt my husband.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your husband? it cannot be: I pitty her, how ſhee's vext?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: How now? what news? nay ſpeake, for we muſt know.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Faith I have found at length by chance where he has been

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: In a blind out-houſe in the Suburbs, pray God all be well with him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: There are his cloaths, but what's become of him, I cannot yet enquire.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am glad of this; ſure they have murtherd him, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Be not ſo grieved before you know the truth, you have time enough to weepe, this is the ſodainſt miſchiefe; did you not bring an Officer to ſearch there, where you ſay you found his cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, and wee ſearcht it, and charg'd the fellow with him: but he like a rogue, ſtubborn rogue, made an|ſwer, he knew not where he was; he had been there, but where he was now, he could not tell: I tell you true I fear him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Are all my hopes and longings to enjoy him,
After this 3 yeares travell, come to this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: It is the rankeſt houſe in all the City, the moſt curſed roguy bawdi-houſe? hell fire it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: This is the worſt I heard yet; will you go home? I'le beare you company, and give you the beſt help I may: this being here will wrong you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: As you are a Gentleman, and as you loved your dead friend, let me not goe home, that will but heape one ſorrow on another.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why purpoſe any thing and I'le perform't; I am at my wits end too.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: So am I, O my deare Maſter!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Peace you great foole.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Then good Sir cary me to ſome retired place, far from the ſight of this unhappy City, whether you will in|deed, ſo it be far enough.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If I might councel you, I think 'twere better to go home, and try what may be done yet, hee may bee at home afore you, who can tell?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O no, I know he's dead, I know hee's murder'd; tell me not of going home, you murder me too.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well, ſince it pleaſes you to have it ſo, I will no more perſwade you to go home, I'le be your guide in the Countrey, as your griefe doth command me, I have a Mo|ther dwelling from this place ſome 20. miles, the houſe though homely, yet able to ſhew ſomething like a wel|come: thither I'le ſee you ſafe with all your ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: With all the ſpeed that may be thought upon; I have a Coach here ready, good Sir quickly; I'le fit you my fine husband.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: It ſhall be ſo; if this fellow be dead, I ſee no band of any other man, to tye me from my will, and I will fol|low her with ſuch carefull ſervice, that ſhe ſhall either be my Love or Wife; will you walke in?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, but one word with my man, and I am ready; keepe the Iriſh fellow ſafe, as you love your life, for he I feare has a deep hand in this, then ſearch a|gen, & get out warrants for that naughty man, that keeps the bad houſe, that he may anſwer it, if you find the body, give it due buriall; farewell. You ſhall heare from mee, keep all ſafe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: O my ſweet M^r!

sp.speaker: Ant. within.
sp.p: Man-a-cree, the Devill take thee, wilt thou kill me here, I prethee now let me goe ſeeke my M^r. I ſhall be very cheel elſe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Do you hear man-a-cree, i'le cree your coxcombe, and you keep not ſtill, down you rogue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Good ſweet fact ſerving-man, let me out I beſeech de, and by my trot I will give dye Worſhip 2. ſhillings in good argott, to buy dy VVorſhip pippines.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: This rogue thinks all the worth of man conſiſts in Peepins; by this light I'le beate rebellion out of you for ever.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Wilt thou not heare me man? is fet, i'le give thee all I have about me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, ſo I may have picking worke,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here is five ſhillings man,
Here is a cudgell, a very good one.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: How now, what's the matter, wher's the Iriſhman.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: There, a wyth take him, he makes more noyſe a|lone there, then ten Lawyers can do with double & a ſcur|vy Caſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Let him out, I muſt talke with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Wilt thou give me ſome drinke, ô hone? I am very dry man.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: You ſhall have that ſhall quench your thirſt, my friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fate doſt thou meane man.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Even a good tough halter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A halter? ô hone!

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Sirha you are a miſchievous rogue, that'● the truth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No fet I am not.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser
sp.p: Shall I knocke out his braines? I have kill'd dogs have been worth three of him for all uſes.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Sirah, the truth on't is, you muſt with mee to a Juſtice. O Roger, Roger.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter William?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Heavy newes Roger, heavy newes, God comfort us.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: What is't man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What's the matter now? I am e'ne weary of this way, wouldl were out on't.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: My Mr. ſure is murdered, Roger, and this curſed rogue feare has had a hand in't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No fet not.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Stand away, i'le kickt out of him: come ſirha, mount, i'le make you dance, you Raſcall, kill my Maſter? If thy breech were cannon proofe, having this good cauſe on my ſide, I would encounter it; hold faire, Shamrocke.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why how now ſirs? you wil not murder me indeed.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Bleſſe us Roger!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, I am no ſpirit.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: How do you Sir, this is my very Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why well enough yet, but you have a heavy foote of your owne; where's my wife?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Alas poor ſorrowfull Gentlewoman, ſhe thinks you are dead, and has given o're houſe-keeping.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whether is ſhe gone then?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Into the Countrey with the Gentleman your friend Sir, to ſee if ſhe can wear her ſorrows out there; ſhe weeps and takes on too too —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This falls out pat; I ſhall be everlaſting for a name: doe you hear? upon your lives and faiths to me, not one word I am living, but let the ſame report paſſe along, that I am murther'd ſtill; I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have a Cauſe Sir that's enough for you; well, if I be not famous, I am wrong'd much; for any thing I know I will not trouble him this weeke at leaſt, noe, let them take their way one of another.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Sir, will you be ſtill an Iriſh-man.?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes a while.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: But your Worſhip will be beaten no more?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No I thanke you William.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: In truth Sir, if it muſt be ſo, I'le doe it better then a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Goe, you are Knaves both, but I forgive you, I am almoſt mad with the apprehenſion of what I ſhall be, not a word I charge you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come pretty ſoul, we now are neer our home,
And whilſt our horſes are walkt downe the hill,
Let thou and I walke here over this Cloſe:
The foot-way is more pleaſant, 'tis a time
My pretty one, not to be wept away,
For every living thing is full of love;
Art not thou ſo too? hah?

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Nay, there are living things empty of love,
Or I had not been here, but for my ſelfe!
Alas, I have too much.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It cannot be, that ſo much beauty, ſo much youth and grace ſhould have too much of love.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Pray what is love? for I am full of that I doe not know.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, love faire maid is an extream deſire,
That's not to be examin'd but fulfil'd,
To aske the reaſon why thou art in love,
Or what might be the nobleſt end in love,
Would overthrow that kindly riſing warmth,
That many times ſlides gently o're the heart,
'Twould make thee grave, & ſtaid thy thoughts would be,
Like a thrice married Widow, full of ends,
And void of all compaſſion, and to fright thee
From ſuch enquiry, whereas thou art now
Living in ignorance, mild, freſh, and ſweet,
And but ſixteen, the knowing what love is,
Would make thee ſixe and forty.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Would it would make me nothing, I have heard
Schollers affirme the world is upheld by love,
But I beleeve women maintain all this,
For ther's no love in men.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, in ſome men.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I know them not.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Why, there is love in me.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Ther's charity I am ſure towards me.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: And love; which I will now expreſſe, my pretty maide,
I dare not bring thee home, my Wife is foule,
And therefore envious, ſhe is very old,
And therefore Jealous; thou art faire and young,
A ſubject fit, for her unlucky vices.
To worke upon, ſhe never will endure thee.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Shee may endure
If ſhe be ought, but Divell, all the friendſhip
That I will hold with you; can ſhe endure
I ſhould be thankfull to you? may I pray
For you and her, will ſhe be brought to thinke
That all the honeſt induſtry I have
Deſerves browne bread? if this may be endur'd,
Shee'l picke a quarrell with a ſleeping childe,
E're ſhe fall out with me.

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: But truſt me ſhe doe's hate all handſomeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: How fell you in love with ſuch a creature?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I never lov'd her.

sp.speaker: Vio,
sp.l: And yet married her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Shee was a rich one.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And you ſwore I warrant you, ſhe was a faire one then too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Or beleeve me I thinke I had not had her.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Are you men all ſuch? wood you wood wall us in a place
Where all we women, that are innocent,
Might live together.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Do not weep at this,
Although I dare not for ſome weighty reaſon
Diſpleaſe my Wife, yet I forget not thee.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: VVhat will you do with me?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt be plac'd
At my mans houſe, and have ſuch food and rayment
As can be bought with money: theſe white hands
Shall never learn to worke, but they ſhall play
As thou ſaiſt they were wont, teaching the ſtrings
To move in order, or what elſe thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, but pray you cloath me poorly,
And let my labour get me meanes to live.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: But faire one, you I know do ſo much hate
A foule ingratitude, you will not looke
I ſhould do this for nothing.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: I will worke as much out as I can, and take as litle
That you ſhall have as duly paid to you
As ever ſervant did.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: But give me now a tryall on't, I may beleeve
We are alone, ſhew me how thou wilt kiſſe
And hug me hard, when I have ſtolne away
From my too clamorous Wife that watches me,
To ſpend a bleſſed houre or two with thee.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Is this the love you mean? you would have that
Is not in me to give, you would have luſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not to diſſemble, or to mince the word,
'Tis luſt I wiſh indeed.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And by my troth I have it not for heavens ſake uſe mee kindely.
Though I be good, and ſhew perhaps a monſter,
As this world goes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I doe
But ſpeak to thee, thy anſwers are thy owne,
I compell none, but if thou refuſe this motion,
Thou art not then for me, alas good ſoule?
What profit can thy worke bring me.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: But I feare: I pray goe, for luſt they ſay will grow
Outragious being deni'd, I give you thankes
For all your courteſies, and there's a Jewell
That's worth the taking, that I did preſerve
Safe from the robbers, pray you leave me here
Juſt as you found me, a poor innocent,
And Heaven will bleſſe you for it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pretty maid I am no Robber nor no Raviſher,
I pray thee keepe thy Jewel, I have done
No wrong to thee, though thou beeſt vertuous
And in extremity, I doe not know,
That I am bound to keepe thee.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: No ſir, for gods ſake if you know an honeſt man in all theſe countries, give me ſome directions to find him out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: More honeſt then my ſelfe good ſooth I doe not know; I would have lain with thee with thy conſent, and who would not in all theſe parts, is paſt my memory, I am ſorry for thee, farwell gentle maid, god keepe thee ſafe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I thanke you ſir, and you;
Woman they ſay, was onely made of man,
Me thinks tis ſtrange they ſhould be ſo unlike,
It may be all the beſt was cut away
To make the woman and the nought was left
Behind with him, I'le ſit me downe and weepe,
All things have caſt me from 'em but the earth;
The evening comes and every little flower
Droops now, as well as I.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Good Madg lets reſt a little, by my troth I am wea|ry, this new pail is a plaguy heavie one, would Tom were hang'd for chooſing it, 'tis the antowardſt foole in a Country.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: With all my heart, and I thanke you too, Nan.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What true contented happineſſe dwells here,
More then in Cities? wood to God my father
Had lived like one of theſe and bred me up
To milke and doe as they doe: me thinks
Tis a life that I wood chooſe, if I were now
To tell my time agen, above a princes; maids for charity
Give a poore wench one draught of Milke
That wearineſſe and hunger have nigh famiſht.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If I had but one Cows Milke in all the world, you ſhould have ſome on't; there drink more, the cheeſe ſhall pay for it, alas poore heart! ſhees dry.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Doe you dwell here abouts?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No, would I did.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madge if ſhe do not looke like my coſen Sue o'th more lane as one thing can looke like another—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay Sue has a hazell eye, I know Sue well, and by your leave not ſo trim a body neither, this is a feate bodied thing I tell you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: She laces cloſe by the maſſe I warrant you, and ſo does Sue too.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I thanke you for your gentleneſſe faire maids.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Drinke agen pray thee.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied, and heaven reward thee for't, yet thus far I will compell you to accept theſe trifles, toyes onely that expreſſe my thanks, for greater worth, I'm ſure they have not in them; indeed you ſhall, I found e'm as I came.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Madge, look you here Madge.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay I have as fine a one as you, mine's all gold and painted, and pretious ſtone in't; I warrant it coſt a crowne wench.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: But mine is the moſt ſumptuous one that ere I ſaw.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: One favour you muſt doe me more, for you are well acquainted here.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Indeed wee'le doe you any kindneſſe ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Onely to ſend me to ſome honeſt place, where I may finde a ſervice.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Vds me, our Dorithy went away but laſt weeke and I know my Miſtris wants a Maid, and why may ſhee not be placed there? this is a likely wench I tell you tru|ly, and a good wench I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: And tis a hard caſe if wee that have ſerved four yeares a piece cannot bring in one ſervant, we will preferr her; harke you ſiſter, pray what's your name?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Melvia.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: A feate name ifaith, and can you milke a Cow? and make a merry-buſh? that's nothing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I ſhall learne quickly.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And dreſſe a houſe with flowers? and ſerve a pigg? this you muſt doe, for we deale in the dary, and make a bed or two?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But be ſure to keepe the men out, they will mar all that you make elſe, I know that by myſelfe; for I have been ſo touz'd among e'm in my days, come you ſhall een home with us and be our fellow, our houſe is ſo honeſt, and we ſerve a very good woman, and a Gentlewoman, and we live as merrily, and dance a good dayes after even-ſong, our wake ſhall be on Sunday; doe you know what a wake is? we have mighty cheer then, and ſuch a coyle, 'twould bleſſe ye; you muſt not be ſo baſhfull, you'l ſpoile all.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Let's home for Gods ſake, my Miſtris thinkes by this time we are loſt, come wee'l have a care of you, I war|rant you; but you muſt tell my Miſtris where you were borne, and every thing that belongs to you, & the ſtran|geſt things you can deviſe, for ſhe loves thoſe extreamly, 'tis no matter whether they be true or no, ſhee's not ſo ſcrupulous; you muſt be our ſiſter, and love us beſt, and tell us every thing, and when cold weather comes wee'l ly together, will you do this?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Then home again a gods name, can you go apace.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I warrant you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: HOw now, any good newes yet?

sp.speaker: Siluio.
sp.l: Faith not any yet.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This comes a tipling; would 'twere treaſon an● pleas'd God to drinke more then three draughts at a meale.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: When did you ſee Richardo?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I croſt him twice to day.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You have heard of a young wench that was ſeen laſt night?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Has Richard hard of this?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes and I thinke hee's ridden after, farewell I'le have another round.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: If you heare any thing, pray ſpare no horſe-fleſhe
I'le do the like.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Do. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sir, I did thinke 'twas you by all diſcriptions.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Tis ſo,
I tooke her up indeed, the manner how
You have heard already, and what ſhe had about her,
As Iewels, gold and other trifling things:
And what my end was, which becauſe ſhe ſlighted,
I left her there i'the feildes.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Left i'th feildes? could any but a Rogue
That had deſpis'd humanity and goodneſſe,
God, law and credit? and had ſet himſelfe
To looſe his nobleſt part, and be a beaſt,
