Have left ſo innocent, unmatch'd a virtue,
To the rude mercy of a wilderneſſe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir If you come to raile, pray quit my houſe,
I do not uſe to have ſuch language given;
Within my doores to me; for your wench,
You may go ſeeke her with more patience,
Shee's tame enough I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Pray forgive me.
I do confeſſe my much forgetfullneſſe;
And weigh my words no farther I beſeech you,
Then a meere madneſſe; for ſuch a griefe has ſeiz'd mee
So ſtrong and deadly, as a puniſhment,
And a juſt one too,
That 'tis a greater wonder I am living,
Then any thing I utter; yet let me tel you thus much,
'Twas a fault for leaving her
So in the fieldes.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Sir I will thinke ſo now, and credit me,
You have ſo wrought me with your griefe, that I
Do both forgive and pitty you:
And if youle pleaſe to take a bed this night heere;
Too morrow I'le bring you where I left her.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I thanke you, no, ſhall I be ſo unworthy,
To think upon a bed, or eaſe or comfort,
And have my heart ſtray from me God knowes where,
Cold and forſaken, deſtitute of friends,
And all good comforts elſe, unleſſe ſome tree
Whoſe ſpeechleſſe charity muſt better ours,
With which the bitter eaſt winds made thier ſport
And ſung through hourely, hath invited her
To keep off halfe a day? ſhall ſhee be thus,
And I draw in ſoft ſlumbers? God forbid.
No, night and bitter coldneſſe I provoke thee,
And all the dewes that hang upon thy locks,
Showers, hailes, ſnowes, froſts, & two edged windes that prime
The maiden bloſſoms, I provoke you all,
And dare expoſe this body to your ſharpneſſe,
'Till I be made a land marke.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Will you then ſtay and eate with mee?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Y'are angry with me, I know you'r angry,
You would not bid me eate elſe; my poore Miſtris,
For ought I know thou art famiſh't, for what elſe
Can the feilds yeeld thee, and the ſtubborne ſeaſon,
That yet holds in the fruite? good Gentle Sir,
Thinke not ill manners in mee for denying
Your offer'd meate, for ſure I cannot eate
While I do thinke ſhe wants; well I'me a raſcall;
A villaine, ſlave, that onely was begotten,
To murder women and of them the beſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is a ſtrange affliction.
If you'le accept no greater courtiſy, yet drink Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now I am ſure you hate me, and you knew
What kinde of man I am, as indeed 'tis fitt,
That every man ſhould know me to avoide me.
If you have peace within you Sir, or goodneſſe
Name that abhor'd word drinke no more unto mee,
You had ſafer ſtrike me.
I pray you do not, if you love me do not.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Sir, I meane no ill by it.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It may be ſo,
Nor let me ſee
None ſir, if you love heaven;
You know not what offence it is unto mee,
Nor good now, do not aske me why:
And I warne you once againe, let no man elſe ſpeake of't,
I feare your ſervants will be prating to me.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Why Sir what aile you?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I hate drinke, ther's the end on't,
And that man that drinkes with meate is dambn'd
without an age of prayers and repentance,
And ther's a hazard too; good Sir no more,
If you will do me a free courtiſy;
That I ſhall know for one, go take your horſe,
And bring me to the place where you left her:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Since you are ſo importunate I will;
But I will wiſh Sir you had ſtay'd to night
Upon my credit, you ſhall ſee no drinke.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Be gon the heating of it makes me giddy,
Sir will you be intreated to forbeare it,
I ſhall be mad elſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I pray no more of that, I am quiet,
I'le but walke in and away ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Now I thanke you,
But what you do, do in a twinckling, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: As ſoone as may bee. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Is this the wench? you have brought me ſome catch I warrant;
How injuringly ſhe looks upon the matter?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: Yes forſooth this is the maiden.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Come hither, wood you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: If it ſhalt pleaſe you to accpt my ſervice I hope I ſhall do ſomething that ſhall like you, though it be but truth, and often praying for you.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: You are very curious of your hand me thinks,
You preſerve it ſo with gloves, let me ſee it;
I marry, here's a hand of march-pane wenches:
This pretty palme never knew ſorrow yet;
How ſoft it is I warrant you, and ſupple:
O' my word this is fitter for a pocket to filch withall
Then to worke, I feare me little one,
You are no better then you ſhould be; goe too.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My Conſcience yet is but one witneſſe to me,
And that heaven knows is or mine innocence,
Tis true, I muſt confeſſe, with ſhame enough,
The time that I have lead yet never taught me
What t'was to breake a ſleep, or to be weary.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: You can ſay well: if you be mine, Wench, you muſt doe well too, for words are but ſlow workers, yet ſo much hope I have of you, that I'le take you ſo you'l bee diligent, and do your duty: how now?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: There is a meſſenger come from your ſon
That brings you word he is return'd from travell,
And will be here this night.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Now joy upon thee for it, thou art ever
A bringer of good tidings, there, drinke that:
In troth thou haſt much contented me, my ſon?
Lord how thou haſt pleas'd me, ſhall I ſee my Son
Yet e're I dye? take care my houſe be handſome,
And the new ſtooles ſet out, and boughes and ruſhes,
And flowers for the window, and the Turky Carpet,
And the great parcell ſalt, Nan, with the Cruets,
And prethee Alexander goe to the Cooke,
And bid him ſpare for nothing, my ſon's come home,
Who's come with him?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I heare of none yet, but a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman? what Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I know not but ſuch a one there is, he ſayes.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Pray God he have not caſt away himſelfe
Upon ſome ſnout-faire piece, I do not like it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No ſure, my Maſter has more diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Well, be it how it will, he ſhall be welcome.
Sirs, to your tasks, and ſhew this little novice
How to beſtir her ſelfe, I'le ſort out things. Exit.

sp.speaker: Madg.
sp.p: We will forſooth, I can tell you my miſtris is a ſ●irring woman.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lord how ſhee'le talke ſome times? tis the mad|deſt cricket—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Mee thinks ſhe talkes well, and ſhewes a great deale of good huſwifry, pray let me deck the chambers, ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes you ſhall, but doe not ſcorne to be avis'd ſi|ſter, for there belongs more to that then you are aware on; why would you venture ſo fondly upon the ſtrow|ings? ther's mighty matters in them I'le aſſure you, and in the ſpreading of a bough pot, you may miſſe if you were ten yeares elder, if you take not a ſpeciall care before you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I will learne willingly, if that be all.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sirrah where is't they ſay my young maſter hath beene?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Faith I know not, beyond the ſea, where they are borne without noſes.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: leſſe bleſſe us! without noſes? how doe they doe for handkerchers?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: So Richard ſaies, and ſirrah, their feet ſtands in their foreheads.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Thats fine by my troth, theſe men have peſtilence running heads then; doe they ſpeake as we doe?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: No, they never ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Are they curſend?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: No they call them Infidells, I know not what they are.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sirrah we ſhall have fine courting now my young maſter is come home, were you never courted ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Alas I know it not.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What is that courting ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I can tell, for I was once courted in the matted chamber, you know the party Madge, faith hee courted finely.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Pray thee what iſt?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Faith nothing but he was ſome what figent with me, faith tis fine ſport, this courting.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Where be the Maids there?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: We ſhall be hang'd anon, away good wenches, and a care you dight things handſomely, I will looke over you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If your ſorrow will give you ſo far leave, pray thinke your ſelfe moſt welcome to this place, for ſo upon my life you are, and for your owne faire ſake, take truce a while with theſe immoderate mournings.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thanke you ſir, I ſhall doe what I may;
Pray leade me to a chamber.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Preſently,
Before your bleſſing mother, I entreate ye
To know this Gentlewoman, and bid her welcome,
The vertuous wife of him that was my ſelfe
In all my travells.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Indeed ſhe is moſt welcom, ſo are you ſon kneele.
Now all my bleſsing on thee; thou haſt made me
Younger by 20 yeares, then I was yeſterday,
Will you walke in? what ayles this Gentlewoman?
Alas I feare ſhe is not well, good Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You feare right.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: She has faſted over long,
You ſhall have ſupper preſently o'th boord.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She will not eate I can aſſure you mother,
For Gods ſake let your maide conduct her up
Into ſome faire becomming Chamber
Fit for a woman of her being and
As ſoone as may be,
I know ſhee's very ill, and wood have reſt.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: There is one ready for her, the blew chamber.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Tis well, I'le leade you to your Chamber doore
And there I'le leave you to your quiet, Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, good reſt to every one,
You'le ſee me once againe to night I hope. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: When you ſhall pleaſe, I'le waite upon you Lady.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Where are theſe maides attend upon the Gentle|woman, and ſee ſhe want no good thing in the houſe? goodnight with all my heart forſooth, good Lord how you are growne? is he not Alexander?

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Yes truly he's ſhot up finely god be thanked.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: An ill weed Mother will do ſo.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: You ſay true Sir, an ill weede growes a pace.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Allexander the ſharpe, you take me very quickly.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Nay I can tell, Allexander will do it, do you reade madcapp ſtill?

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Some times forſooth.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: But faith ſon what countries have you traveld?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why many, Mother, as they lay befor me, France, Spaine, Italy and Germany, and other Provinces that I am, ſure you are not betterd by, when you heare of them.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: And can you theſe tongues perfectly?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Of ſome a little, Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Pray ſpout ſome french ſonne.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You underſtand it not, and to your eares 'twill go like an unſhod cart upon the ſtones, onely a rough un|handſome ſound.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Faith I would faine heare ſome french.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Good Sir ſpeake ſome french to my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: At your entreaty Allexander, I will, who ſhall ſpeake to?

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: If your worſhip will do me the favour Sir, to me.

p.hi: Mounſeir, Poultron, Coukew, Cullione, Beſay, Man cur.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this fine indeed, gods bleſſing 'on thy hart Son, by my troth thou art growne a proper Gentle|man, cullen and pullen, good god what aucey words they uſe beyond the ſeas, ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Did not you ſweare right?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes good Allexander, if you had done ſo to
But good Mother I am very hungry and have rid farr to day and am faſting.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: You ſhall have your ſupper preſently my ſweet Sonne.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: As ſoone as you pleaſe, which once ended,
I'le go and viſit you ſicke gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Come then. Exeun. t.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, like a Poſt, with a letter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have ridden like a fury to make up this worke and I will do it bravely ere I leave it, this is the houſe I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Whood you ſpeake with Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Marry Sir I would ſpeake with a Gentlewoman, came this night late heere from the City, I have ſome letters of Importance to her, I am a Poſt Sir and would bee diſpatch'd in haſt.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Sir, cannot I deliver 'em? for the truth is ſhee's ill and in her chamber.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray pardon me I muſt needes ſpeake with her, my buſineſſe is ſo weighty.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: I'le tell her ſo, and bring you preſent word.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray do ſo, and I'le attend her, pray god the griefe of my imaginde death ſpoyle not what I intend, I hope it will not.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.l: Though ſhe be very ill, and deſires no trouble,
Yet If your buſineſſe be ſo urgent, you may come up and ſpeake with her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thanke you Sir, I follow you. Exeit. Allex.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What ſhould this fellow be i'th name of heaven that comes with ſuch Poſt buſineſſe? ſure my husband hath reveal'd himſelfe, and in this haſt ſent after me, are you the Poſt my friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes for ſooth Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What good newes haſt thou brought me gentle Poſt?
For I have woe and griefe too much already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I would you had leſſe, Miſtris, I could wiſh it, be|ſhrow my hart ſhe moves me cruelly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Have I found you once more Iugler? well Iewell, thou haſt onely vetrtue in thee, of all I read of yet; what eares has this aſſe to betray him with? well, what's your buſineſſe then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have brought a letter from your ſervant, Miſtris, in haſt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray give it me, I hope the beſt ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is the upſhot and I know I have hit it,
Well if the ſpirits of the dead do walke, I ſhall
Heare more of this one hundred yeares hence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By any meanes you muſt have ſpeciall care, for now the Citty is poſſeſt for certaine, my Maſter is made away, which for ought I knowe is a truth indeed; good Miſtris leave your griefe and ſee your danger, and let that wiſe and noble Gentleman with whome you are, bee your right hand in all things.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now do I know I have the better on't by the lan|guiſhing of her eye at this neere inſtant, 'tis ſtil ſimming in her blood, in coyning ſomewhat to turne Mercury I know it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He is my husband, and 'tis reaſonable he ſhould command in all things, ſince he will be an aſſe again the haire at his one perill be it, in the morne you ſhall have a packet, 'till I muſt intreate you ſtay, you ſhall not looſe by it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do not doubt it, Miſtris; I'le leave you to your reſt and waite your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Do, and ſpeake out the Gentleman of the houſe, bid him come to me preſently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who, M^r. Mercury?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Do you know him, poſt?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Onely by ſight forſooth, now I remember your ſervant wild me to let you know he is the onely man, you and your fortunes, are now to reſt upon.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Prethee no more, I know all this already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le take my leave now, I am made for ever. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good night I am provided for you my fine youth

div.stage: Enter Mother beating Ʋiola, Allexander, with a broken glaſſe.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: I'le make thee have more care.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: Good Miſtris pardon me.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Thou't neere be good I warrant thee, can your fine fingers hold no faſter?

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: Indeed it was againſt my will.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Allexander, let's ſee the glaſſe, as, I am true kirſome woman, it is one of the chriſtall glaſſes my cozen ſent mee and the baggage hath broake it where it cannot bee mended, Allexander, can Humfrey mend this thinke you?

sp.speaker: All●x.
sp.p: No truly this will neere be mended.

sp.speaker: Ʋ●ola.
sp.p: T●uly I meant but to waſh it for the Gentlewo|man, that is ſick above, and ſhaking out the water, knockt it againſt the paile ſide.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Did you ſo? be ſure I'le ſtop it, 'twill make a good gap in your quarters wages, can tell you.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: I pray forgive me, and let me have no wages this firſt quarter.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Go whimling, and fetch two or three grating loaves out of the kitching, to make gingerbread of, 'tis ſuch an untoward thing. Exit. Ʋiola.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: Shee's ſomewhat ſimple indeed, ſhe knew not what a kimnell was, ſhe wants good nurture mightily.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: My Sonne tells me, Allexander, that this young widdow meanes to ſojourne here, ſhe offers largly for her board, I may offer her good cheere, prey thee make a ſtep i'th morning downe to the parſonage for ſome Pigi|ons? what are you mad there; what noyſe is that? are you at bowles within? why do you whine?

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: I have done another fault, I beſeech you ſweete Miſtris ofrgive me.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: As I was reaching for the bread that lay upon the ſhelfe, I have throwne downe the minct meate, that ſhould have made the pyes to morrow.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Get thee out of my houſe thou filthy deſtroying Harlot, thou, I'le not keepe thee an howre longer.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: Good Miſtris beate me rather for my fault as much as it deſerves, I do not know whether to go.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: No I warrant thee, out of my dores.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: Indeed I'le mend, I pray ſpeake you for me.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.p: If thou had'ſt hurl'd downe any thing but the pye meate, I would have ſpoake for thee, but I cannot finde in my hart now.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Art thou here yet? I thinke I muſt have an offi|cer to thruſt thee out of my dores, muſt I?

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: Why you may ſtop this in my wages too,
For Gods ſake do, I'le finde my ſelfe this yeare;
And let me ſtay.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thou't ſpoyle ten times as much, I'le cudgell thee out of my dores.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: I am aſſur'd you are more mercifull,
Then thus to beate me and diſcharge me too.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Doſt thou diſpute with mee, Allexander carry the prating hilding forth.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: Good Miſtris heare me I have heere a Jewell,
My Mother left me and 'tis ſomething worth:
Receive it and when all my faultes together
Come to the worth of that, then turne me forth,
'Till then I pray you keep mee.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: What giggombob have wee here? pray god you have not pilfer'd this ſome where; th'art ſuch a puling thing, wipe your eyes, and riſe go your wayes, Allexander, bid the Cook mince ſome more meate, come and get you to bed quickly that you may up betime i'th morning a milking or you and I ſhall fall out worſe yet.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: She has hurt my arme; I am a fraid, ſhe is a very angry woman, but bleſſe him heaven that did me the moſt wrong, I am a fraide Antonious wife ſhould ſee mee, ſhe will knowe mee

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.p: I am coming, ſhee's not angry agen I hope. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Now what am I the better for enjoying
This woman that I lov'd? ſo all I finde,
That I before immaginde to be happy:
Now I have done, it turnes to nothing elſe
But a poore pittied and a baſe repentance,
Udsfoote I am monſtrous angry with my ſelfe:
Why ſhould a man that has diſcourſe and reaſon,
And knowes how neere he looſes all in theſe things,
Covet to have his wiſhes ſatisfied;
Which when they are, are nothing but the ſhame
I do begin to loath this woman ſtraingly,
And I thinke juſtly too, that durſt adventure,
Flinging away her modeſty to take
A ſtranger to her bed, her husbands body
Being ſcarce cold in the earth for her content,
It was no more to take my ſences with,
Then if I had an idle dream had in ſleep
Yet I have made her promiſes: which grieves me,
And I muſt keep 'em too, I thinke ſhe hunts me:
The Devill cannot keep theſe women off,
When they are fletched once.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.l: To bed for gods ſake Sir, why do you ſtay heer?
Some are up i'th houſe, I hard the wife,
Good deare ſweete hart to bed.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Why I am going? why do you follow me?
You would not have it knowne I hope, pray get you
Back to your chamber, the dores hard by for mee,
Let me alone I warrant you, this it is
To threſh well, have got a cuſtomer,
Will you go to bed?

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.l: Will you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes I am going.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.l: Then remember your promiſe you made to marry mee.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I will, but it was your fault, that it came
To this pinch now, that it muſt neede remembrance:
For out of honeſty I offer'd you
To marry you firſt, why did you ſlacke that offer?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas I told you the inconvenience of it,
And what wrong it would appeare to the world
If I had married you in ſuch poſt haſt
After his death: beſide, the fooliſh people
VVould have beene bold to have thought wee had lyen
together in his time, and like enough imagin'd
VVe two had murthered him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I love her tongue yet,
If I were a Saint
A gilded Saint, and ſuch a thing as this
Should prate thus wittily and feelingly
Unto my holineſſe, I cannot tell,
But I feare ſhrewdly I ſhould doe ſomething
That would quite ſcratch me out o'the Kallender,
And if I ſtay longer talking with her,
Though I am mad at what I have done already,
Yet I ſhall forget my ſelfe againe;
I feele the Divell
Ready to hold my ſtirrop; pray to bed, god-night.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This kiſſe, god-night ſweet Love,
And peace goe with thee: thou haſt prov'd thy ſelfe
The honeſteſt man that ever was entic'd
To that ſweet ſin as people pleaſe to call it,
Of lying with anothers VVife, and I,
I thinke the honeſteſt woman without bluſhing,
Th●t ever lay with another man, I ſent my husband
Into a Cellar, poſt, fearing, and juſtly,
He ſhould have knowne him, which I did not purpoſe
Till I had had my end.
VVell, now this plot is perfect, let him bragge on't.

div.head: Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Juſtice, and Curio with a paper.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: BIrlady Sir you have rid hard that you have.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: They that have buſineſſe muſt do ſo I take it.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: You ſay true, when ſet you out my friend?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: About ten a clock and I have rid all night.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: By the maſſe you are tough indeed, I have ſeene the day, I would have rid too with the proudeſt of them and fling durt in their faces, and I have don't with this fooliſh boy ſir many a time; but what can laſt alwayes? 'tis done, 'tis done now Sir, age, care, and office, brings us to our footecloathes, the more the pitty.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: I believe that Sir, but will it pleaſe you to read the buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: My friend I can read an I can tell you when.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Would I could too Sir, for my haſt requires it.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Whence comes it do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Sir from the Citty.

sp.speaker: Juſtice.
sp.p: O from the City 'tis a reverent place.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: And his juſtice bee as ſhort as his memory,
A Dudgion Dagger will ſerve him to mow downe ſinne withall,
What clod pole Commiſſioner is this?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: And by my faith govern'd by worthy member,
Diſcreete and upright.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: Sir they are beholding to you, you have given ſome of them a commendations, they were not worthy of this twenty yeares.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Go to go to, you have a merry meaning, I have found you ſir ifaith, you are a wag, away, fye, now I'le read Your letter.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: Pray do ſir; what a miſery 'tis,
To have an urgent buſineſſe, wait the Juſtice,
Of ſuch an old Tuff taffity that knowes not,
Nor can be brought to underſtand more ſence,
Then how to reſtore ſuppreſt Ale-houſes,
And have his man compound ſmall treſpaſſes,
For ten groates.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Sir it ſeems here your buſineſſe is of deeper circum|ſtance then I conceiv'd it for; what do you meane Sir?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: 'Tis for mine owne eaſe I'le aſſure your VVorſhip.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: It ſhall not be ifaith friend, here I have it,
That one Antonio a Gentleman, I take it ſo,
Yes it is ſo, a Gentleman is lately thought to
Have been made away, and by my faith upon a
Perles ground too, if you conſider; wel, there's
Knavery in't, I ſee that without ſpectacles.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Sure this fellow deals in revelation he's ſo hidden,
Goe thy wayes, thou wilt ſicke a bench ſpit as formally,
And ſhew thy agot, and hatch'd chaine
As well as the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: And now I have conſider'd, I beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: VVhat Sir?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: That he was murdered.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Did you know him?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Nor how it is ſuppos'd.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p:
No, nor I care not two-pence, thoſe are toyes and yet I verily beleeve hee was murdered, as ſure as I beleeve thou art a man, I never failde in theſe things yet, weare a man that's beaten to theſe matters, experience is a certaine conceal'd thing that failes not; pray let me aske you one
thing, why doe you come to me?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Becauſe the letter is addreſt to you, being the nea|reſt Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: The neareſt? is that all?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I thinke it be Sir, I would be Ioth you ſhould bee the wiſeſt.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Well Sir, as it is, I will endeavour in it; yet if it had come to me by name, I know not, but I thinke it had beene as ſoone diſpatcht as by another, and with as round a wiſedome, I, and as happily, but that's all one: I have borne this place this thirty yeares, and upwards, and with ſufficient credit: and they may when they pleaſe, know me better; to the neareſt? well.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: Sir, it is not my fault, for had I knowne you ſooner—

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: I thanke you Sir, I know it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I'le beſworne you ſhould have plaid for any buſi|neſſe now.

sp.speaker: Iuſtice
sp.p: And further, they have ſpecified unto mee, his Wife is ſorely ſuſpected in this matter, as a maine cauſe,

sp.speaker: Curio
sp.p: I thinke ſhe be Sir, for no other cauſe can be yet found.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: And one Mercury a traveller, with whom they ſay directly ſhee is runne away, and as they thinke this way.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I knew all this before.

sp.speaker: Iuſtice.
sp.p: Well Sir, this Mercury I know, and his bree|ding, a neighbours childe hard by, you have been happy Sir in comming hither.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Then you know where to have him Sir?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: I do Sir, he dwells neare me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I doubt your Worſhip dwels neare a Knave then.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.l: I think ſo; pray put on: but 'tis a wonder
To ſee how graceleſſe people are now given,
And how baſe vertue is accounted with them
That ſhould be all in all as ſayes a wiſe man.
sp.p: I tell you Sir, and it is true, that there have beene ſuch murthers, and of late dayes, as 'twould make your very heart bleede in you, and ſome of them as I ſhall bee enabled I will tell you, it fell out of late dayes.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It may be ſo, but will it pleaſe you to proceede in this?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: An honeſt Weaver, and as good a work-man as ere ſhot ſhuttle, and as cloſe: but every man muſt dye; this honeſt Weaver being a little mellow in his Ale, that was the evidence verbatim, Sir, God bleſſe the marke, ſprung his necke juſt ●n this place: wel Iarvis, thou hadſt wrongs, & if I ●●ve ſome of the beſt ſhall ſweat fort, then a wench—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But Sir you have forgot my buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: A ſober pretty maide about 17. they ſay, certainly howſoever 'tis ſhuffled, ſhee burſt her ſelfe, and fondly, if it be ſo, with Furmety at a Churching, but I thinke the Divell had another agent in't: either of which if I can catch ſhall ſtretch for't.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: This is a mad Juſtice that will hang the Devill; but I would you would be ſhort in this, before that other notice can be given?

sp.speaker: Iuſtice.
sp.p: Sir I will doe diſcreetly what is fitting; what, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: within. Your Worſhip?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Put on your beſt coate, and let your fellow Marke goe to the Conſtable & bid him aide me with all the ſpeed hee can, and all the power, and provide pen and inke to take their Confeſſions, and my long ſword, I can|not tell what danger wee may meete with; you'le goe with us?

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: Yes, what elſe? I came to that end to accuſe both parties.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: May I crave what you are?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Faith Sir one that to be knowne would not profit you, more then a meere Kinſman of the dead Antonio's.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: 'Tis well, I am ſorry for my neighbour, truly, that hee had no more grace, 'twill kill his Mother; ſhee's a good olde woman, will you walke in? I'le but put my Cloake on, and my Chaine off, and a cleane band, and have my ſhooes blackt over, and ſhift my Jerkin, and wee'l to our buſineſſe, and you ſhall ſee how I can bolt theſe matters.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: As ſoone as't pleaſe you Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is the place; here did I leave the Maid
Alone laſ● night drying her tender eyes,
Uncertaine what to do, and yet deſirous
To have me gone.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: How rude are all we men,
That take the name of Civill to our ſelves?
If ſhe had ſet her foote upon an earth
Where people live that we call barbarous;
Though they had had no houſe to bring her too,
They would have ſpoil'd the glory that the ſpring
Has deckt the trees in, and with willing hands
Have torne their branches downe, and every man
Would have become a builder for her ſake.
What time left you her there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I left her, when the Sun had ſo much to ſet,
As he is now got from his place of riſe.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: So near the night ſhe could not wander far;
Faire Viola?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is in vaine to call, ſhe ſought a houſe
Without all queſtion.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Peace, faire Viola?
Faire Viola? who ſhould have left her here
On ſuch a ground? if you had meant to looſe her,
You might have found there were no Inches here
To take her name and carry it about,
When her true Lover came to mourn for her,
Till all the neighbouring valleys and the hills,
Reſounded Viola,—
And ſuch a place,
You ſhould have choſe—
You pity us becauſe
The dew a little wets our feete,
Unworthy far to ſeeke her in the wet;
And what becomes of her? where wandred ſhe,
With 2 ſhowers raining on her, from her eyes
Continually, abundantly, from which
There's neither tree nor houſe to ſhelter her;
Will you goe with me to travell?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Over all the world.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No by my faith, I'le make a ſhorter journey
When I do travell.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But theres no hope
To gaine my end in any ſhorter way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, what's your end?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It is to ſearch the earth,
Till we have found two in the ſhapes of men,
As wicked as our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Twere not ſo hard to find out thoſe.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why, if we finde them out,
It were the better; for what brave villany,
Might wee 4. do? wee wood not keepe together:
For every one has treachery enough
For 20. Countryes, one ſhould trouble Aſia,
Another ſhould ſowe ſtrife in Affrica;
But you ſhould play the knave, at home in Europ,
And for America let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ʋale.
sp.l: Sir I am honeſ●e●,
Then you know how to bee, and can no more
Bee wrong'd but I ſhall finde my ſelfe a right.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: If you had any ſparke of honeſty,
You would not think that honeſter then I,
Were a praiſe high enough to ſerve your turne:
If men were commonly ſo bad as I,
Theeves would be put in Callenders for Saints;
And bones of murderers would worke miracles.
I am a kinde of knave, of knave ſo much —
There is betwixt mee and the vileſt elſe,
But the next place of all to mine is yours.

div.stage: Enter 2. Milkemaides, and Ʋiola, with pailes.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: That laſt is ſhe, 'tis ſhee.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let us away, we ſhall infect her, let her have the winde,
And wee will kneele downe here.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: Wenches away for here are men.

sp.speaker: Ʋalerio.
sp.l: Faire maide I pray you ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Alas, agen?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why do you lay hold on her? I pray hartily let her go.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: With all my heart, I do not meane to hurt her.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But ſtand away then for the pureſt bodyes
VVill ſooneſt take infection, ſtand away,
But for infecting her my ſelfe, by heaven,
I would come there and beate thee further off.

sp.speaker: Ʋiola.
sp.l: I know that voyce and face.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: You are finely mad, godbwy Sir, now you are here together, I'e leave you ſo, god ſend you good lucke, both when you are ſoberer, you'le give me thanks. Exit.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: VVilt thou go milke? come.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: VVhy doſt not come?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: She nods, ſhee's a ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: VVhat, wert up ſo early?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: I think your man's mad to kneele there, nay come away ves body, Nan, help ſhe looks black 'ith face, Shee's in a ſound.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And you bee a man com hither, & helpe a woman.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Come thither? you are a foole.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And you a knave and a beaſt that you are.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Come hither? 'twas being my now ſo neare,
That made her ſowne, and you are wicked people,
Or you wood do ſo too, my venom eyes
Strike innocency dead at ſuch a diſtance,
Here I'le kneele for this is out of diſtance.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Th'art a prating Aſſe ther's no goodneſſe in thee,
I warrant, how doſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: Why? well.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Art thou able to go?

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: No, pray go you and milke, if I be able to come
I'le follow you, if not I'le ſit here,
'Till you come back.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am loth to leave thee here with you wild foole.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: I know him well, I warrant thee, he will not hurt mee.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Come then Nan. Exeunt Maides.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: How do you? be not fearefull, for I hold my hands
Before my mouth and ſpeake, and ſo
My breath can never blaſt you.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: 'Twas enough to uſe me ill, though you had ne|ver ſought me too mock me to, why kneele you ſo farr Off, were not that geſture better us'd in prayer, had dealt ſo with you, I ſhould not ſleep, till God and you had both forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I do not mock, nor lives there ſuch a villane
That can do any thing contemptible,
To you, but I do kneele becauſe it is,
An action very fit, and reverent,
In preſence of ſo pure a creature,
And ſo farr off, as fearefull to offend,
One too much wrong'd already.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: You confeſſe you did the fault, yet ſcorne to come,
So far as hither to aske pardon for't;
Which I could willingly afford to come,
To you to grant, good Sir if you have
A better love, may you be bleſt together,
Shee ſhall not wiſh you better then I will,
I but offend you; there are all the Iewels
I ſtole, and all the love I euer had,
I leave behinde with you, I'le carry now
To give another, may the next maide you try
Love you no worſe, nor be no worſe then I.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Do not leave me yet for all my fault,
Search out the next things too impoſſible,
And put me on them when they are effected,
I may with better modeſty receive
Forgiveneſſe from you.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: I will ſet no pennance,
To gaine the great forgiveneſſe you deſire:
But to come hither and take me and it,
Or elſe I'le come and beg ſo you will grant,
That you will be content to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay I will come ſince you will haue it ſo,
And ſince you pleaſe to pardon me I hope
Free from infection, here I am by you;
A careleſſe man, a breaker of my faith,
A lothſome drunkard and in that wild fury:
A hunter after whores I do beſeech you,
To pardon all theſe faultes, and take me up
An honeſt ſober and a faithfull man.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: For gods ſake urge your faultes no more, but mend,
All the forgiveneſſe I can make you is,
To love you which I will do and deſire,
Nothing but love againe, which if I have not,
Yet I will love you ſtill.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: O women that ſome one of you will take,
An everlaſting pen into your hands:
And grave in paper which the writ ſhall make,
More laſting then the marble monuments,
Your matchleſſe vertues to poſterityes:
Which the defective race of envious man,
Strive to conceale.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: Me thinkes I would not now for any thing,
But you had miſt me, I have made a ſtory,
Will ſerve to waſt many a winters fier
When we are old, I'le tell my daughters then,
The miſeryes their Mother had in love:
And ſay my girles bee wiſer, yet I would not
Have had more witt my ſelfe, take up thoſe Iewells,
For I thinke I heare my fellowes coming.

div.stage: Enter the Milkemaides with their pailes.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: How doſt thou now?

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: Why? very well I thanke you, 'tis late ſhall I haſt home?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: I prethee vvee ſhall be ſhent ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: VVhy doe's that railing man go vvith us?

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: I preythee ſpeake vvell of him, on my vvord,
Hee's an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: There was never any ſo one's complexion, a Getleman?
I'de be aſham'd to have ſuch a foule mouth. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mother, Alexander, Andrugio, and his man Rowland.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: How now Alexander, what Gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Indeed forſooth I know not, I found him at the market full of woe, crying a loſt daughter, and telling all her tokens to the people; and wot you what? by all ſub|ſcription in the world, it ſhould be our new maid Melvia, one would little thinke it, therefore I was bold to tel him of her Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Melvia? it cannot be, foole, alas you know ſhee is a poore wench, and I tooke her in upon meere charity.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: So ſeem'd my daughter when ſhee went away, as ſhe had made her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: What ſtature was your childe of, Sir?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Not high, and of a browne complexion, Her haire aborne, a round face, which ſome friends that flattered mee, would ſay 'twould bee a good one.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: This is ſtill Melvia, Miſtriſs, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: It may be ſo I'le promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well, goe thy wayes, the flower of our towne, For a hand and a foote, I ſhall never ſee thy fel|low.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: But had ſhee not ſuch toyes, as bracelets, rings, and Jewels?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Shee was ſomething bolde indeed, to take ſuch things that night ſhe left me.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Then belike ſhe run away?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Though ſhe be one I love, I dare not lye, ſhee did indeed.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: What thinke you of this Jewel?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Yes, this was one of them, and this was mine, you have made mee a new man, I thanke you for it.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Nay, and ſhe be given to filching, there is your Jewell, I am cleare on't: but by your leave Sir, you ſhall anſwer me for what is loſt ſince ſhe came hither, can tell you there lye things ſcattering in every place about the houſe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As I am vertuous, I have the lyingſt olde Gentle|woman to my Miſtris, and the moſt malicious, the De|vill a good word will ſhee give a ſervant, that's her olde rule; and God be thanked they'l give her as few, there is perfect love on both ſides, it yearns my heart to heare the wench miſconſtrued, a carefull ſoule ſhee is i'le be|ſworne for her, and when ſhee's gone, let them ſay what they will, they may caſt their Capps at ſuch a|nother.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: What you have loſt by her, with all my heart
I'le ſee you double paid, for you have ſav'd
With your kinde pitty two that muſt not live
Unleſſe it be to thanke you; take this Jewell,
This ſtrikes off none of her offences, Miſtris,
Would I might ſee her.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Alexander, runne, and bid her make haſt home, ſhee's at the milking Cloſe; but tell her not by any means whoe's here, I know ſhee'l be too fearfull.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Wel, wee'l have a poſſet yet at parting, that's my comfort, and one round, or elſe i'le looſe my will.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: You ſhall finde Silvio, Ʋberto, and Pedro enqui|ring for the Wench at the next Towne, tell them ſhee is found, and where I am, and with the favour of this Gen|tlewoman, deſire them to come hither,

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I pray doe, they ſhall be all welcome. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Juſtice.
sp.p: By your leave forſooth you ſhall ſee me find the parties by a ſlight.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: who's that? Mr. Juſtice? how do you Sir.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Why very well, and buſie, wher's your ſon.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Hee's within Sir.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Hum, and how does the young woman my Cozen that came downe with him.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Shee's above, as a woman in her caſe may be.

sp.speaker: Iuſtice.
sp.p: You have confeſt it? then ſirha call in the Officers; ſhee's no Couzen of mine; a meere tricke to diſ|cover all.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: To diſcover? what?

sp.speaker: Iuſtice.
sp.p: You ſhall know that anon: I thinke you have o|ver reached you; ô welcome, enter the houſe, and by vertue of my warrant which you have there, ſeize up|on the bodily perſons of thoſe whoſe names are there written, to wit, one Mercury, and the wife of one An|tonio.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: For what.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.l: Away I ſay,
This Gentleman ſhall certifie you for what. Exit Officer.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Hee can accuſe my Sonne of nothing, hee came from travell but within theſe two dayes?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: There hangs a tale.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I ſhould be ſorry this ſhould fall out at any time: but eſpecially now Sir; will you favour mee ſo much, as to let me know of what you accuſe him?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Upon ſuſpition of murther.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Murther? I defie thee.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.p: I pray GOD hee may prove himſelfe inno|cent.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Fye, ſay not ſo, you ſhew your ſelfe to be no good Common-wealths man: for the more are hang'd, the better 'tis for the Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: By this rule you were beſt hang your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.l: I forgive your honeſt mirth ever: O, welcome, wel|come Marke.
sp.stage: Enter Marke and Officers, with Mer|cury and the Wife.
sp.l: Your penne, inke, and paper to take their exami|nations.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why do you pull me ſo? I'le goe alone.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Let them ſtand, let them ſtand quietly, whilſt they are examin'd?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What will you examine us of?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Of Antonio's murther.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why, he was my friend.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He was my husband.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: The more ſhame for you both; Marke, your penne and inke.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Pray God all be well, I never knew any of theſe Travellers come to good; I beſeech you, Sir, be favourable to my Sonne.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Gentlewoman hold you content, I would it were come to that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: For gods ſake mother why kneele you to ſuch a pig bribe fellow? he has ſurfetted of geeſe, and they have put him into a fit of Juſtice, let him do his worſt.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Is your paper ready?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: I am ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Accuſe them Sir, I command thee to lay down ac|cuſations againſt theſe perſons in behalfe of the State, and ●irſt looke upon the parties to be accus'd, and deliver your name.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: My name is Curio, my murthered Kinſman
If he were living now, I ſhould not know him,
Tis ſo long ſince we ſaw one another.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My cozen Curio?

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.p: But thus much from the mouths of his ſervants, & others, whoſe examinations I have in writing about me, I can accuſe them of; this Mercury, the laſt night, but this laſt, lay in Antonio's houſe, and in the night he roſe, rai|ſing Antonio, where privately they were in talke an houre, to what end I know not: but of likely-hood, finding An|●onio's houſe not a fit place to murther him in, hee ſuffe|red him to goe to bed againe, but in the morning early, he train'd him I think forth, after which time hee never ſaw his home; his cloathes were found neere the place where Mercury was, and the people at firſt denyed they ſaw him: but at laſt he made a frivolous tale, that there he ſhifted himſelfe into a foote-mans habit: but in ſhort, the next houre this woman went to Mercury, and in her Coach they poſted hither; true accuſations, I have no more, and I will make none.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: No more? wee need no more, Sirha, be drawing heir Mittimus before wee heare their anſwer. What ſay you Sir? are you guilty of this murther?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Whether you are or no, confeſſe, it will bee the better for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If I were guilty, your Rhetoricke could not fetch it forth: but though I am innocent, I confeſſe, that if I were a ſtander by, theſe circumſtances urg'd, which are true, would make me doubtleſs beleeve the accuſed parties to be guilty.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Write downe, that hee being a ſtander by, for ſo you ſee he is, doth doubtleſſely beleeve the accuſed parties, which is himſelfe, to be guilty.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I ſay no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Write it downe I ſay, wee'l try that.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I care not what you write, pray God you did not kill him for my love, though I am free from this, we both deſerve.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Govern your tongue I pray you, all is well, my husband lives, I know it, and I ſee him.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: They whiſper, ſever them quickly I ſay Officers why do you let them prompt one another, Gentlewoman, what ſay you to this, are not you guilty?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No as I hope for mercy.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: But are not thoſe circumſtances true, that this Gentleman hath ſo ſhortly and methodically deliver'd?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: They are; and what you do with me I care not,
Since he is dead, in whome was all my care:
You knew him not.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: No an't bin better for you too, and you had never knew'd him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why then you did not know the worlds chiefe joy
His face ſo manly, as it had been made,
To fright the world, yet he ſo ſweetly temper'd;
That he would make himſelfe a naturall foole,
To do a noble kindneſſe for a friend,
He was a man whoſe name I'le not out live,
Longer then heaven whoſe will muſt be obay'd;
Will have me do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I will quit thy kindneſſe.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Before me ſhe has made the teares ſ●and in mine eyes, but I muſt be auſtere Gentlewoman, you muſt con|feſſe this murder.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I cannot Sir, I did it not, but I de ſire to ſee thoſe examinations which this Gentleman acknowledges to have about him, for but late laſt night I receiv'd letters from the Citty, yet I heard of no confeſſion, then.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee them time enough I warrant you, but letters you ſay you had, where are thoſe letters?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir they are gon.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Gone? whether are they gone?
How have you diſpos'd of 'em?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why Sir they are for womens matters, and ſo I uſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Who writ em?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A man of mine.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: VVho brought 'em?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A Poſt.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: A Poſt? there was ſome great haſt ſure, a ha where is that Poſt?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir there he ſtands.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Doe's hee ſo? bring hither that Poſt, I am afraid that Po●t will prove a knave; come hither Poſt, what? what can you ſay con●erning the murder of Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: VVhats that to you?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: O Poſt, you have no anſwer ready have you? I'le have one from you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You ſhall have no more from mee then you have, you examine an honeſt Gentleman and Gentlewoman heere, 'tis pitty ſuch fooles as you ſhould bee i'the com|miſſion.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Say you ſo Poſt, take away that Poſt, whip him and bring him againe quickly, I'le hamper you Poſt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Tis Antonio, I know him now as well, what an ir|regular foole is this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: VVhip me? hold off.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O good Sir whip him, by his murmuring he ſhould know ſome thing of my husbands death; that may quit me, for gods ſake fetch't out.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Whip him I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: who 'iſt dares whip me now?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O my lou'd husband.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: My moſt worthy friend? where have you been ſo long?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I cannot ſpeake for joy.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: VVhy, what's the matter now, and ſhall not law then have her courſe?

sp.speaker: Andra.
sp.p: It ſhall have no other courſe then it has I thinke

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: It ſhall have other courſe before I go, or I'le beate my braines, and I ſay it was not honeſtly done of him to diſcover himſelfe before the parties accus'd were execu|ted that law might have had her courſe, for then the kingdome flouriſhes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But ſuch a wife as thou, had never any man, and ſuch a friend as he, beleeve me wife, ſhall never be a good wife, love my frend, friend love my wife, harke friend.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Mark. if wee can have nothing to doe, you ſhall ſweare the peace of ſome body.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: By my troth I am ſorry my wife is ſo obſtinate, ſooth if I could yet doe thee any good, I wood, faith I wood.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I thanke you Sir, I have loſt that paſſion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Couzen Curio, you and I muſt be better acquain|ted.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It is my wiſh Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I ſhould not have known you neither, 'tis ſo long
ſince we ſaw, we were but children then: but you have ſhewd your ſelfe an honeſt man to me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I would be ever ſo.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Looke you, whoe's there.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Say nothing to me, for thy peace is made.

sp.speaker: Kic.
sp.l: Sir, I can nothing ſay,
But that you are her Father, you can both
Not only pardon, when you have a wrong,
But love where you have moſt injury.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: I think I ſhall heare of no hanging this yeare, there A Tinker and a Whore yet, the Cryer ſaid that rob'd her, and are in priſon, I hope they ſhall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: No truly ſir, they have broke priſon.

sp.speaker: Inſt.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter, then the Jaylor ſhall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: You are deceiv'd in that to ſir, 'twas known to bee againſt his will, and he hath got his pardon, I thinke for nothing, but if it doth coſt him any thing, 'Ile pay it.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Marke up with your papers, away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O you ſhal ſtay dinner, I have a couple of brawling neighbours, that I'le aſſure you will not agree, and you ſhall have the hearing of their matter.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Go, Gentlemen, go in.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: O Ʋiola, that no ſucceeding age,
Might looſe the memory of what thou wert,
But ſuch an overſwayed ſex is yours,
That all the vertuous actions you can do,
Are but as men will call them, and I ſweare,
'Tis my beliefe that women want but wayes;
To praiſe their deeds, but men want deeds to praiſe.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: THis Comedy long forgot, by ſome thought dead,
By us preſerv'd, once more doth raiſe her head.
And to your noble cenſures does preſent,
Her outward forme, and inward ornament.
Nor let this ſmell of arrogance, ſince 'tis known,
The makers that confeſt it for their owne
Were this way skilfull, and without the crime
Of flatteries I may ſay did pleaſe the time;
The worke it ſelfe too, when it firſt came forth,
In the opinion of men of worth,
Was well receiv'd, and favour'd, though ſome rude
And harſh among the ignorant multitude,
(That reliſh groſſe food better then a diſh,
That's cook'd with care, and ſerv'd into the wiſh,
Of curious pallats) wanting wit and ſtrength,
Truly to judge, condemn'd it for the length,
That fault's reform'd, and now 'tis to be tri'd,
Before ſuch Judges 'twill not be deni'd
A free and noble hearing, nor feare I,
But 'twill deſerve to have free liberty,
And give you cauſe (and with content) to ſay,
Their care was good that did revive this Play.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: 'TIs ended; but my hopes, and feares begin,
Nor can it bee imputed as a ſinne
In me to wiſh it favour, if this night,
To the Judicious it hath given delight,
I have my ends, and may ſuch for their grace,
Vouchſafed to this, finde theirs in every place.
